
Proceedings of the Board of Regents


The University of Michigan


July 1997 - June 1998




JULY MEETING, 1997


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, July 17, 1997
The Regents convened at 1:40 p.m. in the Regents' Room. Present were
President Bollinger and Regents Deitch, Horning, Maynard, McFee,
McGowan, Newman, Power, and Taylor. Also present were Interim Executive Vice President Matthews, Vice President Harrison, Vice President
Hartford, Acting Vice President Neidhardt, Chancellor Renick, and Secretary
Palmer. Vice President Kinnear and Chancellor Nelms were absent. Provost
Machen arrived at about 3:10 p.m.; Vice Chancellor Dorothy Russell
attended in Chancellor Nelms' stead.
Appointment of Provost and Executive Vice President for Academic
Affairs
President Bollinger called the meeting to order and announced his
recommendation for the appointment of Nancy Cantor, dean of the Horace
H. Rackham School of Graduate Studies, as provost and executive vice president for academic affairs.
President Bollinger noted that after Provost Machen announced his
intention to step down from the position of provost, he had appointed a
committee to search for his replacement, with himself as chair. The committee conducted a national search and interviewed several candidates, and
came to the "clear conclusion" that Dean Cantor was "really the right person
for this position at this particular moment."
He observed that during the search process, a feeling of deep respect for
Dean Cantor had been expressed by all sectors of the University of Michigan
community, including staff, faculty, students, and alumni. He then introduced
Dean Cantor to the assembly.
Regent McGowan moved approval of Dean Nancy Cantor as provost and
executive vice president for academic affairs. Regent Deitch seconded the
motion. Several other Regents expressed their enthusiastic support for the
recommendation. The vote was then taken, and the motion was approved
unanimously. There followed a round of applause, after which Dean Cantor
briefly addressed the Board. She expressed how honored she was by the
appointment, appreciation to Provost Machen for his mentoring of her, and
enthusiasm for the prospect of working with President Bollinger and the
Board of Regents.
1997-98 Department of Athletics Budget
President Bollinger called on Mr. Joe Roberson, Director of Athletics, to
present the 1997-98 budget for the Department of Athletics. Mr. Roberson
distributed a handout and gave a corresponding slide presentation. He noted




July Meeting, 1997


that in 1996-97 there were 16 percent more student athletes than in the
previous year, the NCAA graduation rate was 71 percent, and that the
University had won seven conference champions.
Regarding the issue of gender equity, Mr. Roberson noted that it
involves more than issues of proportionality and scholarship opportunities.
Gender equity also is concerned with the broader range of services that
indicate that the genders are treated equally in all aspects of their athletic
competition. He noted that in a recent review by the NCAA, the University
had rated very highly in all of these areas, as well as in the areas of proportionality and gender equity. There are currently 11 men's sports and 12
women's sports, and the department has met totally the NCAA scholarship
limits for men and women.
Regarding the FY1998 revenue budget, Mr. Roberson noted that football
game admissions account for 39 percent of department's budget, while licensing royalties account for 12 percent, post-season revenues account for 9
percent, and TV/Radio revenue account for 10 percent. These figures are
virtually unchanged from the previous year.
Regent Power requested a breakdown of the TV and radio revenue both by
medium and by sport. Mr. Roberson said he would provide that information.
Mr. Roberson noted that the department's total revenue is $39,878,000.
The Regents asked for a breakdown of the amount of revenue from sports
admissions other than football. There was also a discussion about how
television revenue from football is derived, with Mr. Roberson noting that it
comes in the form of revenue sharing through the Big Ten. Michigan's share
of television revenue last year was about $2.8 million, out of a total Big Ten
television revenue of about $36 million. He pointed out that this discussion
highlights the issue of what conferences are and the effect of television on
conferences and on the individual schools within conferences. Noting that
$2.8 million does not represent a very large share of Michigan's athletic
department budget, Regent Power asked how much money the University of
Notre Dame receives from its television contract. He also asked to have the
Big Ten submit its economic model of the media environment over the
medium term and its strategy with respect to the conference and individual
members of it within that environment.  Mr. Roberson said he would
attempt to obtain that information.
In response to a question from Regent Newman, Mr. Roberson explained
how the Bowl Alliance operates. He noted that under this system, certain
conference champions, as well as two at-large bids based on ranking, are
guaranteed an opportunity to go to one of four bowl games. The bowls take
turns getting first choice of teams to play in their bowls.
Regent Power observed that he was asking these questions because the
intersection of big-time athletics and universities is becoming more and more
problematic, and that very large flows of money going into conferences are
driving the contradictions between universities and big-time sports. He believes


2




July Meeting, 1997


that the point is being reached where the conflicts between academics and
athletics will become ever sharper. Mr. Roberson agreed, noting that another
way of stating the problem is to ask the question of whether the University is
in the entertainment business or education business.
There then followed a discussion of graduation rates among University
of Michigan athletes. Mr. Roberson reported that the most recent NCAA
figure is 71 percent for all scholarship athletes. Within this group, the rate is
higher for women than for men, and lower for football and basketball players
than for other male athletes (38 percent for football and 33 percent for
basketball). However, these figures include 2 students on the basketball
team who transferred, and a third who transferred and graduated from
another institution. NCAA figures are based only on students who start at
Michigan but do not receive degrees from Michigan, and do not take into
account those who transfer to other schools, become professional athletes, or
receive degrees beyond the six-year time frame used by the NCAA.
Regent Deitch asked for the graduation rates of athletes who remain at
Michigan and don't transfer, noting that the University is primarily an
educational institution. Mr. Roberson said that he would provide that data.
Regent Newman asked about the status within the NCAA of proposals
whereby all basketball and football players would be ineligible to play their
freshmen year. Mr. Roberson observed that although he is personally in
favor of this proposal, it has been under discussion for years and is unlikely
to ever pass. If an individual institution such as Michigan were to decide to
implement such a policy, it would not only encounter tremendous pressure
from constituent groups, but would be at a competitive disadvantage against
other institutions who do not follow such a policy. The only way such a
system could work is if a large number of institutions subscribed to it, and
that is unlikely to happen.
Regarding expenditures, Mr. Roberson noted that the salaries/wages/
fringe benefits category decreased slightly, while facilities expenditures
increased somewhat. Regent Deitch asked for a breakdown in the salaries
category between the proportion spent on people directly involved in athletics
programs (e.g., coaches, trainers, etc.) and other staff.
In the Department of Recreational Sports, Mr. Roberson noted that 22
percent of the revenue is derived from the General Fund, 12 percent from
student fees, and 66 percent is generated by the department. He observed
that the University's recreational sports department may be the most used
recreational/intramural sports department in the country, used by about 85
percent of students.
Mr. Roberson concluded the presentation with a display of photographs
of various facilities operated by the athletic department. He pointed out that
about $9 million worth of renovations is needed at Crisler Arena.


3




July Meeting, 1997


In response to a question from Regent McGowan about what he would
like to see happen in terms of gender equity in scholarships, Mr. Roberson
noted that last year, the NCAA added 14 scholarship opportunities to women's
sports. This not only increases the proportion of women's scholarships, but
also the opportunities for women to participate in sports in a meaningful
way. He observed that women's sports do not have as many walk-on participants as do men's sports, but providing increased scholarship activities can
help negate this.
University of Michigan Health System's Clinical Delivery System
Operating Budget
President Bollinger noted that one small portion of the health system's
operating budget involves proposed changes in the University's M-Care HMO
and other HMO health care benefits offered to University employees. He
recommended that the Regents not act on the portion of the budget involving
these benefit changes for several weeks, to allow for further consultation
with members of the University.
It was clarified that the benefits in question would apply to all University
employees, not only those who work at the health system, and that if it was
decided ultimately to recommend the proposed changed to the Board, a
special meeting would be called in August for that purpose.
President Bollinger called on Mr. Larry Warren, interim executive director
of the University of Michigan Health System, to present the proposed
FY1998 Clinical Delivery System (CDS) operating budget.
Mr. Warren observed that with the adoption of this budget, the CDS
would continue to make improvements in cost per case and in its other financial objectives. In addition, the work force will be stabilized, which will allow
the CDS to best address the needs of patients, families, and visitors. He
reported that the CDS had reframed its mission, vision, and values statement
so that all staff would have a clear understanding about the leadership's
priorities for the system. The Faculty Group Practice board has also set
expectations in specific areas such as waiting time in clinics; and they and
the leadership have set standards against which they will measure themselves
over time. He also pointed out that the new executive vice president would be
inheriting a healthy health system.
Mr. Warren reviewed the health system's responses to the changing
health care environment, noting that in 1985 the overhead was 55 percent of
the total workforce, and as of 1997 it had been reduced to 35 percent. In the
eleven-year period from 1985-96, the system had reduced its expenses by
$150 million, and last year it set a goal of reducing another $200 million over
a three-year period. Mr. Warren noted that the health system had set a
standard for productivity comparable to that of the best academic medical
centers in the country.


4




July Meeting, 1997


Mr. Warren said that most FY1997 budget objectives had been achieved,
and that the health system had come in under budget in managing expenses.
This resulted in a gain from operations, even though revenues were less than
had been budgeted because the length of stay had been reduced by a greater
amount than had been anticipated. Due to the gain in operations, the staff
would benefit directly through the health system's gainsharing program.
Mr. Warren noted that the FY1998 budget assumptions include
planning for only one budget year, reduced length of stay and admissions
with corresponding growth in clinic visits, a self-funded competitive salary
program, an increase in managed care market penetration, no room rate
increase, and a $45.8 million cost effectiveness program. He commented that
a reduction of an additional 300 positions is required for the health system to
be in the best competitive position it can be. To help achieve that goal, it has
instituted an early retirement incentive program. The intent is to have no
layoffs.
In addition to the retirement incentive, another component of the cost
effectiveness program is a proposal to offer M-Care HMO health care coverage
at no premium charge to University employees. As noted earlier, University
employees would have an opportunity to comment on this proposal before it
is initiated. For FY1998, this proposal would save $2 million, or $4 million
on an annualized basis.
The FY1998 budget calls for $912,212,000 in total operating revenue
and an equal amount in operating expenses.
Regent Power commented that the past year's health system performance
has been very gratifying. Mr. Warren acknowledged the contributions of Mr.
David Southwell, the health system's chief financial officer, and noted that
he will be leaving to assume a new position in Iowa.
1997-98 Operating Budgets and Student Fee Rates, All Three Campuses
President Bollinger called on Provost Machen, who noted that the
fundamental budget objectives are unchanged from previous years: to
maintain and enhance the quality of instructional and research programs;
increase the quality of the undergraduate educational experience; maintain
and enhance access for Michigan undergraduates; and continue to pursue
racial and gender diversity.
He noted that this is the first year the budget was built utilizing the
concept of value centered management (VCM) and reviewed the basic tenets
of that system. He described cost containment and cost reduction efforts
that have occurred in recent years, including reallocating a portion of the
General Fund budget every year, institution of Total Quality Management
("M-Quality"), and re-examination and re-engineering of business processes.
A major goal this year, he noted, has been to reduce the cost of the central
administrative units, while enhancing the resources available to the
academic units. In the General Fund budget, a specific process has been


5




July Meeting, 1997


developed that should lead to a significant reduction in the University's
overall administrative costs.
Provost Machen reported that three parameters were used in the budget
planning process: low tuition and fee increases for both resident and nonresident undergraduates; no increase in the base budget allocations of central
administrative units; and no across-the-board increase in the provost's
allocations to the academic units. He then displayed a table detailing the
recommended General Fund budget broken down by unit, noting that the
state appropriation increase will be 4.18 percent. The average of proposed
undergraduate and graduate/professional school tuition and fee increases will
be 3.44 percent, while the infrastructure maintenance fee is slated to increase
by 9.56 percent, and indirect cost recovery is budgeted to increase by 3.73
percent. The overall increase in General Fund revenue will be 3.94 percent,
while overall expenditures will increase by an equal amount, as described in
the Regents Communication.
Provost Machen announced that the recommended student fee rate
increase for 1997-98 is 2.9 percent for lower and upper division resident and
nonresident undergraduates, with differential increases for specific graduate
programs that reflect special market or cost factors.
Regent McGowan inquired about the budget category of "new presidential
programs." Provost Machen responded that due to the size of the state
appropriation and the decision to freeze administrative costs, he was able to
identify $4 million for use by the president. President Bollinger said these
funds would be used generally for support of academic programs, faculty
salaries, and retaining and recruiting faculty. He also noted that there are
some subject areas that need attention, and that funds will be needed to
accomplish the kinds of improvements that he and the provost believe are
important. The principle purpose of the fund is to stimulate academic
achievement.
Regent Newman noted that the budget for the office of the executive
vice president and chief financial officer remains the same in this budget,
and she expressed the hope that this figure can be reduced next year.
Regent Power observed that this budget is significant because it is the
first to be brought forward under VCM. He noted that the presentation
clearly outlined how VCM is working, and that he appreciated the distinction
between VCM as a decision-making environment and the General Fund as an
accounting environment. Regent Power also pointed out that this budget is
the first to have as a specific policy objective and as a budget reality to lower
the costs of central administration by shifting resources from administrative
to academic activities.
President Bollinger observed that the costs of higher education are of
great concern to the public, even though he personally believes that public
opinion on this issue is exaggerated. However, it is incumbent upon the
University of Michigan as a public institution to be attentive to the public


6




July Meeting, 1997


concerns. He also said that it is also important to realize that a new budgeting
structure like VCM also requires a lot of close attention to make sure that
what is valued at the University is not lost.
President Bollinger recognized the efforts of Provost Machen in implementing VCM, noting that it was not easy and that it was done as skillfully
as it could possibly have been done. He also noted that a lot of progress has been
made in working with the state legislature, with the help of Associate Vice
President Cynthia Wilbanks and other members of Vice President Harrison's
staff.
Regent Deitch commented that he believes the budget is moving in the
right direction. He said he has always appreciated the University's accessibility, and that college expenses are significant for families, even though in
the larger scheme of things, the cost might be considered a bargain. Therefore,
the modest budget increase and the shifting of resources represent a beginning
step in making a statement about the University's priorities. He noted that
this is an important budget that would be looked at historically as a
watershed.
1997-98 UM-Dearborn General Fund Budget and Student Fee Rates
Chancellor Renick reported that the proposed overall increase in tuition
and fees for the Dearborn campus is 2.9 percent. This represents an increase
in faculty positions, a modest salary program, and financial aid support.
1997-98 University Health Service Fee
Vice President Hartford announced a proposed increase of $2.50 per
student per term (2.38 percent) for the 1997-98 University Health Service
fee. The majority of the increase will be used to fund a merit-based salary
program for health service staff.
There followed a 15-minute break, after which the meeting reconvened
to hear public comments at 4:00 p.m.
Public Comments
The Regents heard comments from the following people, on the topics
indicated: Marcia Federbush, citizen, on gender equity in athletics; Mel Larson,
citizen, on an agreement of cooperation between the City of Ann Arbor and
the University of Michigan; and Elaine Sims, co-chair, Commission for Women,
on the UMHS paid time off program.
The business meeting then continued, at 4:17 p.m.
University of Michigan Health System's Clinical Delivery System
Operating Budget
Regent McGowan moved to approve the FY1998 UMHS Clinical Delivery
System's Operating Budget, with the caveat that the portion of the budget


7




July Meeting, 1997


which pertains to M-Care preference, as it has been described today, will be
considered at a subsequent meeting. Regent McFee seconded the motion.
In response to Regent Newman's question about the impact of the
M-Care preference initiative on the overall budget, President Bollinger stated
that it would lead to a revenue increase of $1 million this year and $2 million
in subsequent years, depending on how many people take advantage of the
proposal.
Regent Newman stated that she does not believe this decision should be
delayed, because she feels strongly that the UMHS budget, including the
M-Care preference initiative, should be adopted. There followed a discussion
about the impact of the motion on the rest of the UMHS budget. Regent
Newman emphasized that she did not want to approve a health system
budget that is not balanced, and she believes strongly in the concept of steering University employees toward the University's own health system.
Regent Power observed that the Regents always try to allow people time to
comment on significant items prior to voting on them. He noted that this is
a significant proposal involving fringe benefits that will affect a lot of people,
and until now it has been considered only in the context of the medical center,
rather than the entire University. The motion will provide the community
an opportunity to comment on what is to them a significant issue.
Regent McGowan summarized that the recommendation from the health
system is to provide a certain amount of revenue for its budget. It is now up
to the central administration to determine whether or not to bring to the
Regents that element of the budget. Because this idea has not been discussed
outside of the hospital community, it will come as a surprise to the rest of
the University. The motion is therefore an attempt to adjust the process in
order to allow the University community to comment on the proposal.
President Bollinger concurred, noting that since the health system
budget was put together, it has been brought to his attention that there are
concerns about the process used for this particular proposal because it will
affect staff benefits. It is possible that the administration may decide not to
recommend it at this time.
Regent McFee suggested that there be a time certain when the proposal
will be brought back for a discussion and/or vote. Regent Maynard concurred.
Regent Deitch stated that based on the information they now have,
many of the Regents believe this is a good idea, and that if the vote were to
be taken today, he would vote to approve the M-Care preference initiative.
However, because of the big impact such a decision would have, and because
he values discussion and input, he could possibly be convinced to change his
mind if confronted with a compelling argument. He requested that the
Regents reconvene, and if the administration decides not to recommend it,
he would like the opportunity to weigh that point of view. He observed that
the proposal highlights the fact that this is one institution with limited


8




July Meeting, 1997


resources, and that it represents an opportunity to direct dollars into other
areas and help the hospital, thereby helping the whole institution.
It was noted that in order to have sufficient lead time to prepare materials regarding open enrollment in the benefits program, a decision would have
to be made by August 15.
Regent Power concurred that the administration ought to bring forward
at a special meeting no later than August 15 a recommendation either for or
against the proposal. There followed a discussion about whether the proposal
should be brought forward if the administration ultimately decides not to
recommend it after receiving public comment. Regent Deitch suggested that
if the decision is not to recommend the proposal, then a vote should be taken
on a replacement for the revenue that it would have generated. Therefore, a
decision one way or the other should be made at a meeting in August.
Regent Taylor commented that the president understands the sense of
the Board, that the proposal needs to be brought back in time to be implemented, and that a vote will be taken either for or against at a meeting in
August. Regent McGowan responded that she believes that would be an unfortunate scenario.
Regent Power summarized that the UMHS budget would be voted on
today, minus the portion relating to M-Care preference, with the understanding that by August 15th, the Regents would be asked to vote either to
approve the M-Care preference or to vote on another means of balancing the
budget.
Regent McGowan withdrew her original motion, and Regent Deitch
moved a substitute motion, to adopt the FY1998 UMHS Clinical Delivery
System's Operating Budget with the caveat that by August 15 the Regents
convene by a duly called conference telephone call, for a meeting to act upon
a recommendation from the president with regard to M-Care preference or
an alternative, which in the president's judgment would be an appropriate
revenue substitute for M-Care preference if it is not so recommended.
Regent Power seconded the motion.
There followed a discussion about whether the vote in August would be
on the entire CDS budget, or on only the portion that pertains to M-Care
preference. Regent McFee suggested that the vote be tabled until the following morning. Regent McGowan pointed out that she would be absent then.
Regent McFee stated that she would like to find a way to resolve the
issue of a balanced budget, and deferring the vote until the next day seemed
to be the logical way to do this. Regent McFee moved to table the vote on
Regent Deitch's motion until the following day. Regent Newman seconded
the motion, and it was approved unanimously.

Resolution in Honor of J. Bernard Machen
Regent Horning read the following resolution:
Regents' Resolution
The Regents of the University of Michigan commend and express
their deepest appreciation to J. Bernard Machen as he completes his
two-year term as provost and executive vice president for academic
affairs on August 31, 1997.
Provost Machen assumed the University's top academic post at a
crucial time of transition for the University. He quickly mastered the
intricacies of the demanding job of provost, and he provided invaluable guidance and counsel to the Regents during the presidential
search. Accessible, forthright, resolute, and precise in carrying out his
duties, Provost Machen earned the admiration and respect of faculty
and staff, deans, and the Regents. He opened discourse with faculty
on a number of important issues, including the faculty grievance
process, and oversaw implementation of Value Centered Management,
a major change in the University's budgeting system.
Provost Machen came to the University of Michigan as dean of
the School of Dentistry in 1989. Prior to that, he held teaching and
administrative posts at several universities and served as a major in


10




July Meeting, 1997


the U.S. Army Dental Corps. He received his D.D.S. degree from St.
Louis University and earned his M.S. degree in pedodontics and his
Ph.D. degree in educational psychology, both from the University of
Iowa.
Provost Machen's wife, Chris, has been a strong supporter of the
University and of the work of the provost's office. Always gracious, she
has encouraged collegiality by frequently hosting social events to bring
together faculty and spouses from across the University. She also has
been an enthusiastic supporter of University events, regularly attending official functions, athletic contests, and student-sponsored
programs.
With admiration and deep gratitude for their numerous contributions to the University, and particularly for their leadership during a
time of transition, the Regents extend their best wishes and appreciation to Bernie and Chris Machen.
Following a round of applause, Provost Machen thanked the Regents
and said how much he had enjoyed his tenure as provost. There followed a
standing ovation.
President's House Renovation
Regent Power made the following motion:
The President's House was built in 1840 and is listed on the National
Register of Historic Places. It is the oldest building on campus and an
important part of the history of the University. Originally built as a professor's house, the President's House symbolizes the long and continuous
academic tradition that is so close to the heart of this institution.
When he became president in February, President Bollinger
announced his intention to make the President's House more visible as a
center of the intellectual life of the University, and indeed, in these first six
months has hosted breakfasts, lunches, and dinners as well as informal
events there. He has expressed his intention to hold even more events there,
and from time to time, to host the most distinguished visitors to the University as guests in his house.
To that end, plans have been developed to refurbish and renovate
substantial parts of the second and third floors of the home. Although refurbishment projects of this size do not normally require Regental approval, the
Regents wish to go on record to applaud President Bollinger for his initiative
in bringing the house more to the center of University life and to authorize
the use of up to $250,000 from undesignated gifts to the University for this
purpose.
Regent McGowan seconded the motion. Regent Maynard expressed
support for the motion, noting that the house is a showcase and the president is using it as it should be used.


11




July Meeting, 1997


Regent Power recalled that the first floor of the President's House was
last renovated when President Duderstadt took office, with approval given at
a public meeting, and that it is now appropriate to repeat this process for
renovations to the second and third floors.
In response to a question from Regent Newman about undesignated
gifts, Executive Vice President Matthews stated that these are bequests that
are made with no strings, and that either the principal or interest can be
used for any purpose at all. Regent Newman expressed the view that principal not be used, as she did not believe that donors necessarily may have
expected their donations to be used for furnishings for a home.
Regent Taylor expressed strong disagreement, noting that he did not
believe that it was proper to speculate on what donors mean when they
direct that their gifts be used for unspecified and unrestricted purposes; he
believes their intentions should be taken at face value.
Regent Deitch noted that in the context of an overall budget that
exceeds $2 billion, amounts of $250,000 or $1 million could be viewed as a
"slip of the pencil;" however, as stewards of these funds, the Regents are
responsible for accounting for them. He believes this is an appropriate use of
University funds, given that the president is the leader of the institution, the
house is in the center of the campus, and the president has pledged to have it
serve as a home and a place that represents the hospitality of the University
and the center of its intellectual life. Therefore, appropriately outfitting it is
an appropriate use of $250,000, and whether the funds used come from interest or principal is irrelevant.
Regent Horning commented that he has talked to several individuals
who have been entertained recently in the house and had reported a "warm
feeling again in Ann Arbor and the University that they hadn't felt recently."
He commended the president for using the house in this way and expressed
support for the motion.
The vote was then taken, and the motion was approved unanimously.

July Meeting, 1997


Friday, July 18, 1997
The Regents met at 9:30 a.m. in the Regents' Room. Present were
President Bollinger and Regents Deitch, Horning, Maynard, McFee,
Newman, Power, and Taylor. Also present were Provost Machen, Interim
Executive Vice President Matthews, Vice President Harrison, Vice President
Hartford, Acting Vice President Neidhardt, Chancellor Nelms, Chancellor
Renick, and Secretary Palmer. Regent McGowan and Vice President
Kinnear were absent.
President Bollinger called the meeting to order and called on Chancellor
Nelms.
UM-Flint 1997-98 General Fund Budget and Tuition and Fee Rates
Chancellor Nelms reviewed the budget proposal, noting that it had
three objectives: to maintain quality and affordability for students; to
provide greater access to technology for students, faculty, and staff; and to
enhance the retention and success of students. The budget represents the
smallest tuition and fee increase on the Flint campus since 1985-86 (about
$47.00 per semester for tuition and $15.70 in fee increases for lower division
undergraduate students). He noted that much of the fee increase would be
used directly to support student activities related to their majors. The technology fee is to be used exclusively for the acquisition of computer hardware and
software to support students.
Regent Maynard moved approval of the 1997-98 UM-Flint General Fund
budget. Regent Horning seconded the motion.
In response to a question from Regent Newman about the percentage
increases, Chancellor Nelms noted that for lower division undergraduate
students, the tuition increase amounts to 2.9 percent and the combined
tuition and fee increase is 3.6 percent. The combined tuition and fee
increase for upper division undergraduate students is slightly greater than
4.0 percent.
There being no further discussion, the vote was then taken on the
General Fund budget, and the motion was approved unanimously.
Regent Maynard moved approval of the proposed UM-Flint tuition and
fee rates for 1997-98, as described in the Regents Communication. Regent
Power seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
University of Michigan Health System's Clinical Delivery System
Operating Budget
Regent Power moved to approve the FY1998 UMHS Clinical Delivery
System's Operating Budget, with the caveat that the portion of the budget
which pertains to M-Care preference, as it has been described, will be considered at a subsequent meeting. If M-Care preference is eliminated, the


13




July Meeting, 1997


administration will propose to the Regents a plan for balancing the UMHS
budget. Regent Deitch supported the motion.
It was determined that the meeting would have to be held within about
two weeks, and it was confirmed that the meeting could be in the form of a
conference call. Vice President Harrison said that if the meeting were held
by conference call, it would be made accessible to the press and public.
The vote was then taken, and the motion was approved unanimously.
1997-98 Revenue and Expenditure Budgets
Regent Power moved approval of the revenue and expenditure operating
budgets for 1997-98, with the caveat that the portion of the budget which
pertains to M-Care preference in the UMHS Clinical Delivery System's
Operating budget will be considered at a subsequent meeting. Regent McFee
seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
Consent Agenda
Minutes. Secretary Palmer submitted minutes of the June 1997 meeting.
Reports. Executive Vice President Matthews submitted Reports of
Investments, Plant Extension, Litigation, Human Resources and Affirmative
Action, and Non-Competitive Purchases over $5,000 from Single Sources
from April 1 through June 30, 1997.
Vice President Neidhardt submitted Reports of Projects Established and
Summaries of Current Research and Sponsored Projects for June 1997. He
noted that the technology transfer program has been very successful. Based
on current licensing contracts and equity holdings, the University's revenues
from technology transfer during this fiscal year are expected to be nearly
triple that of last year's, exceeding $6 million. Regent Power complimented
Vice President Neidhardt on a very encouraging report, noting that the
Regents had spent a lot of time modifying technology transfer policies.
Vice President Neidhardt reported on the activities of the Year of
Humanities and the Arts ("YoHA"), which will take place during the 1997-98
academic year.
Voluntary Support. The final report of fiscal-year gift receipts,
including the totals for the month of June, will be presented in the September meeting.
Personnel Actions. Provost Machen submitted a number of personnel
actions. President Bollinger noted that Ms. Chacona Johnson would be
joining his office as chief of staff, while also retaining her appointment in the
Office of the Vice President for Development.

Retirement Memoirs. Seven retirement memoirs were presented to
the Regents.
Richard E. Czarnecki, professor of business administration at the
UM-Dearborn School of Management, retired from active faculty status on
April 30, 1997.
Professor Czarnecki received his B.S. (1953) and M.B.A. (1957) degrees
from the University of Detroit, and his Ph.D. degree in 1965 from Michigan
State University. From 1955-68, he was a professor at the University of
Detroit. He joined the faculty of the University of Michigan-Dearborn as a
visiting professor of business administration in 1968 and was promoted to
professor in 1969.
A beloved and dedicated educator, Professor Czarnecki has served with
great distinction throughout his career. A well-recognized leader in the
accounting profession, he has won top honors in the field from such organizations as the Michigan Association of Certified Public Accountants, the
American Institute of Certified Public Accountants, and the National
Association of State Boards of Accountancy. In recognition of teaching and
professional excellence, he has received the UM-Dearborn Distinguished
Teaching Award, the Michigan Association of Governing Boards' Distinguished Faculty Award, the MACPA Distinguished Service Award and
Distinguished Achievement Award, and the AICPA Accounting Educator-ofthe-Year award an unprecedented four times. He has also served as member
and chair of the Michigan State Board of Accountancy and director-at-large
of the National Association of State Boards of Accountancy.
On May 22, 1997, at "A Tribute to Dick Czarnecki," organized by
alumni and colleagues, Professor Czarnecki received a special proclamation
signed by Governor John Engler and the leaders of the state house and
senate. The proclamation recognized Professor Czarnecki as "a highlyrespected educator, administrator, and member of the accounting profession,
who served the academic community, the state of Michigan, and his students
with distinction for over four decades." Known as a devoted educator who
never forgets a name, the three tribute albums that Professor Czarnecki
received at the event, containing over 300 letters from former students and
colleagues, were especially meaningful. He also received the first-ever
Chancellor's Medal from Chancellor James C. Renick, in recognition of his
exceptional contributions to UM-Dearborn.
The Regents now salute this dedicated teacher and senior member of the
Dearborn campus by naming Richard E. Czarnecki professor emeritus of
business administration.


28




July Meeting, 1997


Mary Lou Kemme, assistant professor of psychology, Department of
Psychiatry, retired from active faculty status on June 30, 1997, after a
productive career as a teacher, clinician, and diagnostician.
Professor Kemme received her A.B. degree from Calvin College in 1959
and her A.M.. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Michigan in 1961
and 1971, respectively. Between 1960-71, she was a clinical psychology
intern at Children's Psychiatric Hospital, University Counseling Center, and
the Department of Pediatrics at the University of Michigan. As a teaching
assistant, she provided individual and group supervision of psychodiagnostic
methods. She also was a consultant with Perry Nursery School, Washtenaw
County Community Mental Health and York Woods Center. She joined the
University of Michigan as an instructor in 1971 and was promoted to assistant professor in 1974.
Professor Kemme's primary expertise was in the field of child psychotherapy. She was involved in clinical supervision of psychiatric residents,
psychology interns and fellows, and social work students. From 1983-84, she
served as psychology training director for child psychiatry, and in 1984, she
was associate chief psychologist for the Child Service. She was administrative program director for the Child Inpatient and Day Hospital Service from
1984-85 and served as program director of the Day Hospital for Children and
Adolescents from 1985-89. She has been a member of the American Psychological Association since 1971 and a member of the Michigan Psychological
Association since 1974.
Professor Kemme's devoted loyalty as teacher, clinician, and diagnostician has been recognized over the years. Her insightfulness, expertise, and
contributions to the department have been consistently recognized by
faculty, trainees, and staff.
The Regents now salute this distinguished member of the faculty for her
dedicated service by naming Mary Lou Kemme assistant professor emerita of
psychology in the Department of Psychiatry.
Sylvan Kornblum, professor of psychology, College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts, and research scientist in the Mental Health Research
Institute and professor of psychology in the Department of Psychiatry,
Medical School, retired from active faculty status on June 30, 1997, after a
productive career as a research psychologist.
Born in Antwerp, Belgium, Dr. Kornblum emigrated with his family to
New York City and graduated from the Bronx High School of Science in
1945. He received his B.A. degree in 1951 from Washington University and
his A.M., M.S., and Ph.D. degrees, in 1953, 1955, and 1960, respectively,
from the University of Michigan. He joined the University of Michigan
faculty in 1959 as an associate research psychologist. He was promoted to
research psychologist in 1970, research scientist in 1974, and professor of
psychology with tenure in the Department of Psychiatry in 1975. He has
held his title in the Department of Psychology, College of Literature, Science,
and the Arts, since 1991.
Dr. Kornblum is internationally known for his novel approach to the
study of human performance. Human performance is often determined by
whether the stimuli and the responses in a task match or not: if they match,


29




July Meeting, 1997


performance is usually better and easier than if they do not match. The
theory that Dr. Kornblum has been developing over the past several
years-the Dimensional Overlap Model-postulates that matches may result
from perceptual, conceptual, or structural similarities between the stimulus
and the response sets. Matches may also reflect the strength of association
between stimuli and responses. The results of experiments he has been
conducting extends the theory to other fundamental cognitive processes and
suggests that the family of tasks studied taps basic human cognitive
capacities.
The Regents now salute this distinguished educator and scientist for his
dedicated service by naming Sylvan Kornblum professor emeritus of psychology, research scientist emeritus, and professor emeritus of psychology in the
Department of Psychiatry.
Paul R. Lehman, senior associate dean and professor of music, School
of Music, and lecturer, School of Education, will retire from active faculty
status on August 31, 1997.
A native of Athens, Ohio, Professor Lehman received his B.S.Ed. degree
from Ohio University in 1953 and his M.Mus. and Ph.D. degrees from the
University of Michigan in 1959 and 1962, respectively. He was a public
school teacher in Ohio from 1953-55 and served in the U.S. Air Force in
Tripoli from 1955-57. Between 1962 and 1975, he taught at the University
of Colorado, the University of Kentucky, and the Eastman School of Music at
the University of Rochester and served for a year as a music specialist with
the U.S. Department of Education. He joined the faculty of the University of
Michigan in 1975 as a professor of music. He was appointed associate dean
in 1977 and senior associate dean for graduate studies in 1989.
Professor Lehman has served the Music Educators National Conference
continuously since 1964 in several dozen roles, including its presidency from
1984-86. Since 1992, he has been regularly involved in a wide variety of
standards-related publications and activities, and he chaired the task force
that developed the voluntary national standards for K-12 instruction in
music. He has served on the board of directors of the International Society
for Music Education, the executive board and council of the College Music
Society, and in leadership posts in several other influential music education
agencies. He was project director for the National Symposium on the Applications of Psychology to the Teaching and Learning of Music. He has served
as a consultant to state departments of education, state assessment
programs, school districts, foundations, corporations, and to the National
Endowment for the Arts, National Endowment for the Humanities, and the
U.S. Department of Education. He has addressed music educators in almost
every state and in a dozen nations, and he is the author of more than 100
publications concerned with curriculum, teacher education, and measurement and evaluation. He has received citations from the Music Educators
National Conference, National Federation of Music Clubs, Foundation for
the Advancement of Education in Music, the Alumni Society of the University of Michigan School of Music, and other music educators' associations.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming
Paul R. Lehman professor emeritus of music.

July Meeting, 1997


Philip M. Margolis, M.D., professor of psychiatry, retired from active
faculty status on June 30, 1997, after a most productive career.
Dr. Margolis received his B.A. (1945), B.S. (1947), and M.D. (1948)
degrees from the University of Minnesota. He completed an internship at
Milwaukee County Hospital (1948-49) and a psychiatry residency at the
Veterans Administration Hospital and University of Minnesota Hospitals
(1949-52). He was a fellow with the U.S. Public Health Service at Massachusetts General Hospital in 1952-53, and he also received additional graduate
training in psychoanalysis.
From 1953-55, Dr. Margolis was an instructor at the University of
Minnesota, and from 1955-66, he was an assistant professor, then associate
professor, at the University of Chicago. He joined the faculty of the University of Michigan in 1966 as professor of psychiatry. He was director of the
Washtenaw County Community Mental Health Center from 1966-72, and in
1969, he received a joint appointment as professor of community mental
health in the School of Public Health. Dr. Margolis served as associate chief
of clinical affairs from 1981-85. In 1985, he helped establish and served as
the first chair of the University of Michigan Hospitals Ethics Committee. He
has also served on the Medical School Admissions Committee.
Dr. Margolis has been a leader in many state and national organizations.
He is a life fellow of the American Psychiatric Association and has been
active in a number of its affiliated organizations. He has served as president
of the Michigan Psychiatric Society and the Washtenaw County Medical
Society. Dr. Margolis served on the Michigan Board of Medicine and is a
member of the board of directors of the Federation of State Medical Boards.
He is a diplomate of the American Board of Psychiatry and Neurology and
has been an examiner for the board for thirty years. Within the University,
Dr. Margolis founded and organized the annual Raymond W. Waggoner
Lectureship on Ethics and Values in Medicine in the Department of Psychiatry. He is a resolution officer for the Code of Student Conduct and is chair of
the Civil Liberties Board. In recognition of Dr. Margolis' devotion as a
teacher and clinician, he was given an appreciation award by psychiatric
residents in 1991 and a career service award by the Mental Health Association of Michigan in 1992.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his
dedicated service by naming Philip M. Margolis professor emeritus of
psychiatry.
William Martel, M.D., the Fred Jenner Hodges Professor of Radiology,
will retire from active faculty status on August 31, 1997, after a most productive career as a teacher, researcher, and clinician.
Dr. Martel received his B.S. (1950) and M.D. (1953) degrees from New
York University. After serving his internship at Kings County Hospital in
Brooklyn and residency at Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York City from
1953-57, he joined the University of Michigan Medical School as an instructor in 1957. He was promoted to assistant professor in 1960, associate professor in 1963, and professor in 1966. During his 40 years at the University of
Michigan, Dr. Martel served in numerous capacities, including chief of the
Section of Musculoskeletal Radiology, director of the Radiology Residency


31




July Meeting, 1997


Training Program, director of clinical services, and from 1982-92, as chair of
the Department of Radiology.
Throughout his career, Dr. Martel has been a strong advocate for the
role of radiology in medical student education. When he was not personally
directing the department's efforts, he encouraged and guided others in their
participation. Dr. Martel is an accomplished teacher, both in informal
settings at the viewbox and as a lecturer. He has served as a faculty advisor
to numerous medical students considering a career in radiology and has
frequently taught informally small groups of students interested in
additional exposure prior to beginning their internships. In 1979, he was
awarded the University's Amoco Outstanding Teaching Award. The citation
noted "his sincere dedication to the teaching of medicine, his special talent
for imparting his knowledge and inspiring students to develop their own
latent faculties. His teaching emphasized the common sense approach to
medical diagnosis and his enthusiastic manner, scholarly attitude, and keen
sense of humor left a lasting impression." Dr. Martel's contributions were
further recognized in 1985 when he was named the Fred Jenner Hodges
Professor of Radiology.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health educator for his
dedicated service by naming William Martel, the Fred Jenner Hodges Professor Emeritus of Radiology.
James M. Miller, associate professor of industrial and operations
engineering, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1997.
Professor Miller received his B.S. degree in 1963, his M.B.A. degree in
1965, and his Ph.D. degree in 1971, all from The Ohio State University. He
began his career at the University of Michigan as assistant professor of
industrial and operations engineering (IOE) in 1971 and was promoted to
associate professor in 1976.
Professor Miller developed new courses in safety management, occupational and product safety engineering, safety engineering research, and legal
and labor issues in industrial engineering. He co-founded the IOE Occupational Health and Safety graduate program  and traineeship, and with
another faculty member, initiated the University's multi-disciplinary
program in rehabilitation engineering. Within the Dental School, he initiated the application of work measurement and methods engineering to
operative dental practices.
Professor Miller's work on motor carrier safety is well-known, and he
has also contributed greatly to the field of recreational boating safety. His
two volumes that define future directions for the U.S. Coast Guard's
research program in recreational boating safety and human factors are
particularly significant, and he continues to be known as the foremost
authority in this area.
In collaboration with Mark Lehto, Professor Miller also initiated
research that led to publication of the book Warnings: Fundamentals, Design
and Evaluation Methodologies, in 1986. This book has gained international
recognition and continues to be an authoritative source. The approaches he
pioneered are becoming the standard in the design of on-product labeling.


32




July Meeting, 1997


During the Carter administration, Professor Miller was appointed to act
as director of safety standards for the Occupational Safety and Health
Administration (OSHA). He has also assisted the Consumer Product Safety
Commission on numerous occasions. Most recently, he was asked to conduct
user research and develop the safety labeling that will appear on every
all-terrain vehicle sold in the United States after 1997.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming James M. Miller
associate professor emeritus of industrial and operations engineering.

33




July Meeting, 1997


Sale of Tax-Exempt Commercial Paper by the University
Executive Vice President Matthews called on Associate Vice President
Norman Herbert. Associate Vice President Herbert noted that the Regents
had previously authorized the issuance of debt secured by a pledge of general
revenues and the development of a structure for the sale of commercial
paper. The proposed commercial paper program would provide interim
financing to University projects which require the issuance of debt.
Refinancing of the outstanding $3.9 million of Regents of the University of
Michigan Variable Rate Demand Intercollegiate Athletic Revenue Bonds,
Series 1995, will also be included in the commercial paper program, resulting
in additional savings.
Mr. Herbert explained further details about the commercial paper
program, all of which are contained in the Regents Communication. Following his presentation, Regent Power moved, and Regent Newman seconded, a
resolution authorizing the issuance of up to $120 million of commercial
paper supported by a pledge of general revenues.
Mr. Herbert then commented further on the implications of this
program. He noted that in the past, the University had used fixed rate debt,
which has a higher interest rate than variable rate debt or commercial paper.
The lower financing costs achieved by using commercial paper ultimately
lead to a higher return on investments.
Regent Deitch observed that commercial paper is a method of financing
for the largest and most credit-worthy borrowers, and it deals with short-term
needs for cash. Mr. Herbert noted that the only time the amount of the
outstanding commercial paper would be increased would be based on approved
projects; the Board would be informed each time this is contemplated.
Following further discussion, the vote was taken and the motion was
approved unanimously. The following is the text of the approved resolution:
RESOLUTION OF THE REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
AUTHORIZING THE ISSUANCE AND DELIVERY
OF COMMERCIAL PAPER NOTES, SERIES A,
AND PROVIDING FOR OTHER MATTERS RELATING THERETO
WHEREAS, the Regents of the University of Michigan (the "Issuer")
constitutes a constitutional body corporate established pursuant to Article VIII,
Section 5 of the Michigan Constitution of 1963, as amended, with the general
supervision of the University of Michigan (the "University") and the control and
direction of all expenditures from the University's funds; and
WHEREAS, the Issuer has determined it is necessary and desirable to
provide for the temporary financing of capital projects of the University currently
under way or to be undertaken within the next succeeding eighteen months,
through the issuance of Regents of the University of Michigan Commercial Paper
Notes, Series A (the "Notes"), in principal amount outstanding from time to time
not to exceed $120,000,000; and
WHEREAS, the Issuer has determined it is necessary and appropriate to
refund through the issuance of Notes the outstanding balance of the Issuer's
$5,000,000 Regents of the University of Michigan Variable Rate Demand

July Meeting, 1997


Intercollegiate Athletic Revenue Bonds, Series 1995 (the "Prior Bonds"), issued
for the purpose of financing improvements to the athletic plant at the University
(collectively, the "Prior Project"); and
WHEREAS, the Issuer has approved certain capital projects to be temporarily financed in whole or in part through the issuance of the Notes, and may
approve additional projects to be so financed in the next eighteen months (all
such projects, together with the Prior Project being herein called the "Projects");
and
WHEREAS, in order to provide for the issuance of the Notes, it will be
necessary for one or more of the executive vice president and chief financial

Issuing and Paying Agent Agreement (the "Paying Agent Agreement") with a
bank to be selected by an Authorized Officer, and one or more Dealer Agreements
(each a "Dealer Agreement") with a dealer or dealers (collectively, the "Dealer")
to be designated by an Authorized Officer; and
WHEREAS, the Notes are to be limited and not general obligations of the
Issuer, payable from and secured by a pledge of General Revenues (as defined in
the Issuance Certificate) and to be additionally payable from Available Investments (as defined in the Issuance Certificate); and
WHEREAS, The Issuer has previously issued certain series of bonds or
notes (the "Senior Lien Indebtedness") secured by and payable from Student Fees
or other revenue streams (other than Hospital Gross Revenues and Medical
Service Plan Revenues) which comprise a portion of General Revenues, and it is
intended that each series of the Senior Lien Indebtedness remain outstanding and
continue to be secured, until paid or defeased, by its respective revenue stream on
a senior lien basis to the Notes and other General Revenue indebtedness subsequently issued, but that no new Senior Lien Indebtedness is to be issued; and
WHEREAS, it is necessary for the Issuer to delegate to each of the Authorized Officers the power to designate certain Authorized Representatives and
Authorized Persons (each as defined in the Issuance Certificate or Paying Agent
Agreement) to undertake certain actions with respect to the issuance of Notes;
and
WHEREAS, the Notes authorized hereby are to finally mature on or before
July 1, 2000, and are intended to be replaced by permanent General Revenue
financing on or prior to such date; and
WHEREAS, in the exercise of its constitutional duties, and in order to
prudently control and direct expenditures from the University's funds, the Issuer
determines it is necessary and desirable to authorize the issuance of the Notes to
provide funds to temporarily finance and refinance all or part of the costs of the
Projects, and to pay certain costs incurred in connection with the issuance and
sale of the Notes; and
WHEREAS, in order to be able to market the Notes, it is necessary for the
Issuer to authorize an Authorized Officer to prepare, execute and deliver, on
behalf of the Issuer, an Offering Memorandum (as supplemented from time to
time, the "Offering Memorandum") to be circulated and used in connection with
the marketing, sale and delivery of the Notes, and to take, together with other
appropriate officers, agents and representatives of the Issuer or the University,
additional actions necessary to accomplish the sale and delivery of the Notes, the
administration of the commercial paper program of which the Notes are a part,
and the purposes hereof, all within the limitations set forth herein; and

REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY          OF MICHIGAN      COMMERCIAL PAPER
NOTES, SERIES A, in the aggregate principal amount outstanding from time to
time as shall be designated by any two Authorized Officers, but not in excess of

shall be determined by an Authorized Officer, for the purpose of financing and

to pay all or part of the costs incidental to the issuance of the Notes. The Projects
as a whole are hereby determined by the Issuer to constitute a single governmental purpose of the Issuer. The Notes shall not be subject to redemption prior to
maturity. Each Note shall mature not later than 270 days after its date of
issuance, as shall be determined as provided in the Issuance Certificate and
Paying Agent Agreement, and all Notes must mature on or before July 1, 2000.
Interest on each Note shall be payable on the maturity date thereof, at the rate,
not in excess of 12% per annum, to be determined as specified in the Issuance
Certificate and Paying Agent Agreement. The Notes shall be issued in fully registered form, or registered to bearer, in the denominations, shall be subject to
transfer and exchange, and shall be executed and authenticated, all as shall be
provided in the Issuance Certificate. The Notes shall be sold at par through the
Dealer selected by an Authorized Officer, as provided in the Dealer Agreement.
2. The Notes shall be limited and not general obligations of the Issuer
payable from and equally and ratably secured by a lien on General Revenues,
subject only to the senior liens on portions of General Revenues securing the
respective series of Senior Lien Indebtedness (until each respective series of such
Senior Lien Indebtedness is paid or defeased in accordance with its terms), and
moneys from time to time on deposit in the Note Payment Fund created pursuant
to the Issuance Certificate, as provided therein. The Notes shall also be payable
from Available Investments, as provided in the Issuance Certificate. The Issuer
shall covenant in the Issuance Certificate that so long as any of the Notes remain
outstanding, the Issuer will not issue any new series of Senior Lien Indebtedness.
No recourse shall be had for the payment of the principal amount of or
interest on the Notes or any claim based thereon against the state of Michigan,
or, except as provided in the Issuance Certificate, the Issuer, or against any
officer or agent of the Issuer or of the University, as individuals, either directly or
indirectly, nor shall the Notes and interest with respect thereto become a lien on
or be secured by any property, real, personal or mixed of the state of Michigan,
the Issuer, or the University, other than the General Revenues and the moneys
from time to time on deposit in the Note Payment Fund created by the Issuance
Certificate.
3. The right is reserved to issue additional bonds, notes or other obligations
payable from and secured by General Revenues on a parity basis with the Notes
as to the lien on General Revenues, but subject to the prior liens on portions
thereof securing Senior Lien Indebtedness.

Addition and Renovation (Student Design Team Project Center)
Executive Vice President Matthews called on Mr. Doug Hanna, University architect, to present the plans for the Student Design Team Project
Center. He said that the purpose of the project is to establish space for
students to form teams to work on high profile engineering projects, such as
the concrete canoe, hybrid electric vehicles, solar cars and solar boats. He
displayed diagrams illustrating a site plan and interior plan, described details
of the interior space plan, and displayed an architectural model of the
finished project.
Dean Director of the College of Engineering commented that this facility
would provide much needed and versatile space for engineering students.
Regent McFee moved approval of the Engineering Programs Building
and Plasma Research Building addition and renovation project, as described.
Regent Newman seconded the motion. President Bollinger noted that the
physical location of this project also has the potential to highlight this area of
campus, which contains a sculpture by the artist Maya Lin. It was noted
that Ms. Lin was involved in developing the plans for the building in an
effort to enhance her sculpture.
The vote was then taken, and the motion was approved unanimously.

Executive Vice President Matthews noted that the Kellogg Building

of architect, had been approved in November 1996. It has since been determined that additional needs exist for lecture rooms and expansion and
renovation of the Pediatric Dental Clinic, in addition to certain building
renewal work.
Mr. Doug Hanna displayed a site plan, revised design and floor plan, and
a rendering of the exterior. Regent Power moved approval of the revised
scope, budget, and design of the Kellogg Building Expansion and Renovation
Project, and authorization for solicitation of bids and awarding of a construction contract to the successful bidder, providing the project remains within
the approved budget. Regent Maynard seconded the motion.


38




July Meeting, 1997


It was noted that the incremental cost of the revised project is about $6
million. There being no further discussion, the vote was taken, and the

Palmer Drive Parking Structure
Executive Vice President Matthews noted that the Regents had previously approved a project for construction of a parking structure on open land
east of the Dental School, and had authorized a site development study to
analyze the long range development potential of the area surrounding the
site. He called on Mr. Fred Mayer to present the results of the site development study.
Mr. Mayer described the physical topography of the site and how this
would affect the plan. Other factors which would impact the plan include
traffic patterns; utilities issues; soils; issues having to do with the operation
of the heating plant; service and access issues; use of the space above the
parking structure; the effect of the various structures in the plan on views of
the campus; phasing of the development; and whether or not to keep North
Hall.
Mr. Mayer revealed a model containing blocks of wood whose purpose is
to estimate gross square footage that would fit on the space. He arranged
the blocks of wood in several configurations to illustrate various schemes for
placement of buildings, and to demonstrate that there are a number of
options available for developing the site, and then responded to comments
from the Regents.
Mr. Hanna noted that planners expect to be able to bring a proposed
design for the parking structure for review by the Regents at a future
meeting.
President Bollinger commented that he has had a number of discussions
with University planners and architects about this project, and that he
intends to propose that a master plan be developed for the entire campus.
He noted that this is a key site for the future of the University of Michigan
because the current thinking is that it is the last remaining building site on
the central campus. Its location also points out the psychological and physical barrier between the Medical School, the residence halls, and the central
campus that is created by Washtenaw Avenue. He believes that eventually
this street could become an underpass.
President Bollinger also said that science education at the University is
very important, but that the various science departments are at scattered
locations on central campus and on the medical campus. Linking these
various science departments is a major issue for the University, and also has
an impact on the development of this space. The construction of a parking
lot seems consistent with all of the options for the future of the space.

collaborate with the University's researchers.

his position as a member of the board of directors of, MEDOX Electro-Optics,
Inc.

Residency Guidelines
Regent Power moved approval of "Information on Residency Classification for Admission and Tuition Purposes" and "Residency Classification
Guidelines" (both of which shall be referred to as the "Guidelines") as a
replacement for the 1974 Residence Regulations, effective Spring Term,
1998, and a change in the make-up of the Residency Appeals Committee,
effective immediately. Regent Maynard seconded the motion.
Provost Machen noted that the new guidelines do not contain any
significant changes in the practices or policies of the University with respect
to residency determinations. Their purpose is to help students better understand the requirements they must satisfy to be eligible for residency and the
process they must follow to obtain residency.
Regent Newman complimented the staff on the revised guidelines,
noting that a lot of effort had gone into developing them, and said that she
will be interested to see how well they work. Regent McFee observed that in
her years of service on the board she had been approached a number of times
about residency issues, and that these guidelines appear to provide clarification of what is required. She suggested that the guidelines be forwarded to
high schools.
Regent Newman left the meeting at this point, at 11:15 a.m. Provost
Machen noted that this project had had significant input from the secretary
of the University and from the general counsel, and is one of the last projects
that had been undertaken by Associate Vice President Susan Lipschutz
before she died.
There being no further discussion, the vote was taken, and the motion
was approved unanimously. The text of the Guidelines is contained in the
appendix (page 45).

Section 5.07. Administrative Officers of Other University Units
Administrative officers of units other than those covered by Sec. 5.06 shall be
appointed by the Board on recommendation by the president. They shall perform such
administrative duties as are prescribed by the appropriate University authorities.
Appointments to such administrative positions are without tenure and may be
terminated upon the request of the appointee for relief from administrative duties or
by the action of the Board.
