JULY MEETING, 1997
APPENDIX A
UNIVERSITY OF MICHIGAN
INFORMATION ON RESIDENCY CLASSIFICATION
FOR ADMISSION AND TUITION PURPOSES
Authority
The governing board at each university in Michigan has the authority to determine
residency classification guidelines for admission and tuition purposes. Therefore, residency
guidelines may vary from school to school and are independent of guidelines used by other
state authorities to determine residency for purposes such as income and property tax liability,
driving, and voting.
The following guidelines were approved by the University of Michigan's Board of
Regents to take effect spring term 1998 and to apply to students at all campuses of the
University of Michigan. The guidelines are administered by the Residency Classification
Office in the Office of the Registrar at the Ann Arbor campus, 1514 LS&A Building, University
of Michigan, Ann Arbor, MI 48109-1382, (734) 764-1400.
The Student's Responsibilities and the Residency Application Process
It is the student's responsibility to read the University Residency Classification Guidelines
contained in this document and to apply for admission and register under the proper
residency classification. It is also the student's responsibility to file an Application for
Resident Classification for an official determination of status. Students are encouraged to
consult with staff in the Residency Classification Office if they have questions or assistance.
The admissions offices at the various schools and colleges within the University perform the
initial screening for residency classification. If a student indicates Michigan resident status
on the admissions application and the admissions office questions that status, the student
will be classified as a nonresident and notified of the need to file an Application for Resident
Classification with the Residency Classification Office. The fact that a student's claim to
residency for University purposes is questioned does not necessarily mean that he or she will be
ineligible; it simply means that the student's circumstances must be documented and
reviewed by the Residency Classification Office. Failure on the part of admissions staff to
question a student's claim to resident eligibility does not relieve the student of the responsibility to apply and register under the proper residency classification. Furthermore, the University reserves the right to audit enrolled or prospective students at any time with regard to eligibility for resident classification and to reclassify students who are registered under an
improper residency classification.
Until an Application for Resident Classification is filed and approved, a student who
previously attended any campus of the University of Michigan as a nonresident will continue
to be classified as a nonresident at all campuses.
Upon application for admission to any campus of the University, an individual who
claims eligibility for resident classification must file an Application for Resident Classification
for an official determination of status if any of the following circumstances apply:
* the individual is living out of state at the time of application to the University
* either parent is living out of state (applies if the individual is 24 years of age
or younger)


45




July Meeting, 1997 - Appendix A


*    the individual has attended or graduated from an out of state high school
(applies if the individual is 24 years of age or younger)
*    the individual has attended or graduated from an out of state high school
and has been involved in educational pursuits for the majority of time since
graduation from high school
*    the individual has had out of state employment or domicile within the last 3
years
The above list is not exhaustive. An individual is responsible for filing an application for
resident classification in any situation where the individual's eligibility for residency under
these guidelines could be reasonably questioned.
Filing Deadlines
Students may apply for resident classification for any term in which they are enrolled
or intend to enroll. The deadline dates for filing the Application for Resident Classification
are the same for all University of Michigan schools, colleges, and campuses.* The following
dates apply to the term for which residency is sought If the deadline falls on a weekend, it
will be extended to the next business day.
Fall Term.... September 30
Winter Term.... January 31
For all Spring, Spring/Summer, and Summer Terms.... July 31
* For the On Job/On Campus program, filing deadlines are 30 calendar days after the
first scheduled day of classes.
Documentation Which Must Be Included When Filming for Resident Classification
When filing an Application for Resident Classification, the following documentation
must be included with the application form:
*    for all applicants: a copy of the driver's license of the applicant and of the
person or persons upon whom the applicant is basing the claim to resident
eligibility
* for all applicants: copies of the front and signature pages of the most recent
year's federal and state income tax returns and W2s for the applicant and
the person or persons upon whom the applicant is basing the claim to
resident eligibility
*   for applicants born outside the U.S.: verification of U.S. citizenship or visa
status
*   for applicants who are dependents: (see Residence Classification Guideline
B-l) copies of the front and signature pages of the parents' most recent
year's federal and state income tax returns
*   for applicants whose claim to eligibility for resident classification is based on
permanent full-time employment for themselves, a parent, spouse, or domestic partner: a letter from the employer, written on letterhead (including
phone number), stating the position, status and dates of employment. The letter
should be accompanied by a copy of the most recent pay stub showing Michigan
taxes being withheld.
Applicants are also responsible for providing any other documentation necessary to
support their claim to resident eligibility. Additional documentation may be requested by the
Residency Classification Office.


46




July Meeting, 1997 - Appendix A


Appeal Process
If an Application for Resident Classification is denied by the Residency Classification
Office, the student may request that his or her file be reviewed by the University's Residency
Appeal Committee. The appeal request must be made in writing and must be received in the
Residency Classification Office within 30 calendar days of the date on the denial letter. If the
deadline falls on a weekend or University holiday, it will be extended to the next business day.
All contact with the Residency Appeal Committee must be in writing. Personal contact
with a member of the committee prior to the meeting could disqualify the member from
participating in the decision. A student who wishes the committee to consider additional
information must submit the information to the Residency Classification Office, in writing,
with the appeal request The information will then be forwarded to the Residency Appeal
Committee with the student's file.
The student will receive a written decision from the committee when the review is
complete. Once the Residency Appeal Committee issues its decision there are no further
appeals for the term covered by the application.
Misrepresentation and Falsification of Information
Applicants who provide false or misleading information or who intentionally omit relevant
information in an application for admission, an application for resident classification, or any
other document relevant to residency eligibility may be subject to legal or disciplinary
measures. Students improperly classified as residents based on this type of information will
have their residency classification changed and may be retroactively charged nonresident
tuition for the period of time they were improperly classified.
Residency Classification Guidelines
For University purposes. "domicile" is defined as the place where an individual intends
his/her true, fixed, and permanent home and principal establishment to be, and to which the
individual intends to return whenever he or she is absent. These Guidelines are designed to
explain how a student may demonstrate the required intent and establishment of a domicile in
Michigan. An individual whose activities and circumstances, as documented to the University,
demonstrate that she/he intends to be domiciled in Michigan has, in fact, established a
domicile in Michigan will be eligible for classification as a resident. An individual whose
presence in the state is based on activities or circumstances that are indeterminate or temporary,
such as (but not limited to) educational pursuits, will be presumed not to be domiciled in
Michigan and will be classified as a nonresident. The burden of proof is on the applicant to
demonstrate with clear and convincing evidence that he or she is eligible for resident classification
under these guidelines.
These guidelines describe situations that create presumptions of resident and nonresident
status. The fact that a presumption of resident status may apply to a student does not mean
that the student will automatically be classified as a resident or that the student is relieved
of the responsibility for filing an Application for Resident Classification. (See The Student's
Responsibilities and the Residency Application Process on page 1.) To overcome a presumption
of nonresident status, a student must file a residency application and document with clear
and convincing evidence that a Michigan domicile has been established.
A. GENERAL GUIDELINES
1.   Circumstances which may demonstrate permanent domicile
The following circumstances and activities, though not conclusive or exhaustive
may lend support to a claim to eligibility for resident classification:


47




July Meeting, 1997 - Appendix A


* both parents (in the case of divorce, one parent) permanently
domiciled in Michigan as demonstrated by permanent employment,
establishment of a household, and severance of out of state ties
* applicant employed in the state in a full-time, permanent
position provided that the applicant's employment is the primary
purpose for the applicant's presence in Michigan
* spouse or domestic partner employed in the state in a full-time,
permanent position provided that the spouse or partner's employment is the primary purpose for the student's presence in Michigan
2.   Circumstances which do not demonstrate permanent domicile
The circumstances and activities listed below are temporary or indeterminate
and, in and of themselves, do not demonstrate permanent domicile:
*    enrollment in high school, community college, or university
*    participation in a medical residency program, fellowship or internship
*    employment that is temporary or short-term
*    military assignment
*    employment in a position normally held by a student
*    ownership of property
*    presence of relatives (other than parents)
*    possession of a Michigan driver's license or voter registration
~    payment of Michigan income or property taxes
~    the applicant's statement of intent to be domiciled in Michigan
3.   One year continuous presence
In cases where it is determined that an applicant has not demonstrated establishment of a domicile in Michigan as defined by these guidelines, the University will
require the applicant to document one year of continuous physical presence in the
state as one of the criteria for determining eligibility for resident classification in
any subsequent Application for Resident Classification. The year to be
documented will be the one year immediately preceding the first day of classes of
the term in question. The year of continuous presence is never the only criterion
used for determining resident eligibility, and, in itself, will not qualify a student for
resident status. If substantial and new information arises which changes the circumstances of a student's presence in Michigan and which clearly demonstrates the establishment of a Michigan domicile, the student may be immediately eligible for
resident classification prior to the passage of one year.
In documenting the year of continuous physical presence in Michigan, the applicant will be expected to show actual physical presence by means of enrollment,
employment, in-person financial transactions, health care appointments, etc.
Having a lease or a permanent address in the state does not, in itself, qualify as
physical presence. Short-term absences (summer vacation of 21 days or less,
spring break, and break between fall and winter term), in and of themselves, will
not jeopardize compliance with the one year requirement. In determining the
effect of a short term absence, the nature of the absence will be assessed to determine whether it is contrary to an intent to be domiciled in Michigan. Absences
from the state in excess of the time mentioned above or failure to document
physical presence at the beginning and end of the year will be considered as
noncompliance with the one-year continuous presence requirement.


48




July Meeitmg, 1997 Appendix A


Bo  IRESIDENCY PRESUIMPTIONS IN PARTICULAR             CIRCU$UMSTANCCES
The fact that a presumption of resident status may apply to a student does not mean
that the student will automatically be classified as a resident or that the student is
relieved of the responsibility for filing an Application for Resident Classification. (See
The Student's Responsibilities and the Residency Application Process on page 1.)
1. Depende Sdent Students
For University residency classification purposes, a student is presumed to be a dependent of his or her parents if the student is 24 years of age or younger and (1) has
been primarily involved in educational pursuits, or (2) has not been entirely financially self-supporting through employment
a    Residents
i.   Dependent Student - Parents in Michigan
A  dependent sdenent whose parents are, according to University
Residency Classification Guidelines, domiciled in Michigan is presumed to
be eligible for resident classification for University purposes as long as the
student has not taken steps to establish a domicile outside of Michigan or
any other action inconsistent with maintaining a domicile in Michigan.
ii.  Dependent Student of Divorced Parents - One Parent in Michigan
A dependent student whose parents are divorced is presumed to be
eligible for resident classification for University purposes if one parent
is, according to University Residency Classification  Guidelines,
domiciled in Michigan. The student mut   not have taken steps to
establish an independent domicile outside of Michigan or any other
action inconsistent with maintaining a domicile in Michigan.
iii.  Dependent Resident Student Whose Parents Leave Michigan
A student who is living in Michigan and who is, by University
Residency Classification Guidelines, permanently domiciled in Michigan does not lose resident status if the parents leave Michigan,
provided (1) that the student has completed at least the junior year of
high school prior to the parents' departure, (2) that the student
remains in Michigan, enrolled as a full-time student in high school or
an institution of higher education, and (3) that the student has not
taken steps to establish a domicile outside Michigan or any other
action inconsistent with maintaining a domicile in Michigan.
b.   Nonresidents
Dependent Student - Parents not in Michigan
A dependent student whose parents are domiciled outside the state of Michigan
is presumed to be a nonresident for University purposes.
2.   Michigan Residents and Absences From the State
Individuals who have been domiciled in Michigan according to University
Residency Classification Guidelines immediately preceding certain types of
absences from the state may retain their eligibility for resident classification
under the conditions listed below:
a    One Year Absence
An individual who has been domiciled in Michigan immediately preceding
an absence from the state of less than one year may return to the University


49




July Meeting, 1997 - Appendix A


as a resident for admission and tuition purposes provided (1) that the
individual has maintained significant ties to the state during his or her
absence, and (2) that the individual severs out of state ties upon returning
to Michigan.
While a student described in this subsection is presumed to have retained
his/her eligibility for resident classification, an individual who has been
absent from the state in excess of one year (and who does not fall within the
circumstances described at (b) - (c) below) may still be able to prove eligibility for resident classification if the student 1) has not established a domicile
outside Michigan; 2) demonstrates the continuous maintenance of a Michigan domicile throughout his/her absence (e.g. payment of Michigan taxes,
maintenance of Michigan driver's license and Michigan voters registration,
active bank/business accounts, and parents still in state); and 3) severs all
out of state ties upon returning to Michigan.
b.   Absence for Active Duty Military Service (Army, Navy, Air Force, Marines,
Coast Guard), Missionary Work, Peace Corps, or Similar Philanthropic Work
An individual who is domiciled in Michigan at the time of entry into active
military duty, missionary work, Peace Corps, or similar philanthropic work
does not lose eligibility for resident classification as long as he or she is on
continuous active duty and continuously claims Michigan as the state of
legal residence for income tax purposes. Dependent children of such an
individual are also eligible for resident classification, provided (1) that they
are coming to the University directly from high school or they have been
continuously enrolled in college since graduating from high school, and (2) that
they have not claimed residency for tuition purposes elsewhere.
c.   Absence for Education or Training
An individual who is domiciled in Michigan immediately preceding an absence
from the state for full-time enrollment in school or for a medical residency
program, internship, or fellowship does not lose eligibility for resident classification provided (1) that the individual has maintained significant ties to
the state during his or her absence (e.g., parents still in the state, payment
of state taxes, active business accounts), and (2) that the individual has not
claimed residency for tuition purposes elsewhere.
3.   Residence Status of Immigrants and Aliens
Only persons who are entitled to reside permanently in the United States may be
eligible for resident classification at the University. These individuals, like U.S.
citizens, must still prove that they have established a Michigan domicile as
defined in these guidelines. Having the privilege of remaining permanently in the
United States, in itself, does not entitle a person to resident classification for
University purposes. The Residency Classification Office will review the circumstances of the following classes of immigrants:
*    Permanent Resident Aliens (must be fully processed and possess Permanent
Resident Alien card or stamp in passport verifying final approval by filing
deadline for applicable term)
*  Refugees (1-94 card must designate "Refugee")
*    A, E (primarv'), G and I visa holders *
* Based upon current law, these nonimmigrant visa classifications are the only
ones that permit the visa holder to establish a domicile in the United States. The
University Registrar shall update this list as changes occur in applicable law.

SPECIAL MEETING, AUGUST 1997


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Wednesday, August 6, 1997
A special meeting of the Board of Regents was conducted via conference
telephone call on August 6, 1997, at 11:10 a.m. Present in the Regents'
Room were President Bollinger, Regent McGowan, Secretary Palmer, and
Interim Co-General Counsel Barry. Joining the meeting by telephone were
Regents Deitch, Horning, Maynard, McFee, Power, and Taylor, Executive
Vice President Matthews, and Vice President Harrison. Regent Newman
was unable to participate.
FY 1998 University of Michigan's Health System's Clinical Delivery
System (CDS) Operating Budget
President Bollinger called the meeting to order and said that the issue
before the Board was the approval of the hospital budget. He noted that at
the last meeting it had been decided to postpone this decision until the
administration could consider whether to go ahead with the "M-Care
Preference" proposal. He announced that the administration has decided
not to go forward with M-Care Preference at this time. If it is necessary to
find an additional $2 million in revenues to balance the budget at the end of
the year, these funds would be drawn from the Hospitals' reserves.
M-Care Preference. President Bollinger commented that the original
plan had been to propose the M-Care Preference plan as part of the revenues
in the CDS budget presented at the July Regents' meeting. This proposal
was one of several changes in the compensation program that had been
developed by the health system over the past several years in an attempt to
reduce costs, increase revenues, and generally reorganize the medical center.
He applauded the efforts of Larry Warren, interim executive director of the
Hospitals, in trying to bring the Medical Center into budgetary balance and
said that the University is grateful to him and the health system staff for all
of their efforts.
President Bollinger noted that while most of the proposals regarding
changes in the form of compensation offered to employees applied only to
Hospitals' employees, M-Care preference would have applied to the whole
University. After considering all of the proposals, it was decided to table all
of them except M-Care preference. In May, after meeting with several
campus groups for advice on whether to proceed with the M-Care preference
initiative, administrators believed it was the appropriate thing to do.
However, by the time of the July Regents' Meeting, it became increasingly
evident that perhaps there had been insufficient discussion of the issue.
Therefore, at the July meeting, he suggested that the Regents approve
the budget without M-Care preference included, opening the way for an


51




Special Meeting, August 1997


opportunity to have further discussion about the issue. The Board decided
instead to withhold action on the entire budget until discussions had been
held about M-Care preference, and that is the purpose of the current
meeting. President Bollinger noted that based on the feedback received since
the July meeting, he had concluded that further discussion was needed about
this and the other compensation items mentioned earlier.
President Bollinger cautioned that it should not be concluded that the
University is ungrateful for the efforts that have been made at the Hospitals,
nor does the administration want to convey that it will back down from
economic decisions that it believes are important for the University simply
because there is opposition. He also emphasized that it should not be
concluded that M-Care preference is being eliminated from consideration in
the future. Rather, he is proposing that this issue, along with the other
items, needs to be subjected to further campus discussion. The risks of not
doing so are not only that no new ideas will be elicited, but that there will be
an antagonism towards the Medical Center that, however unjustified, could
arise simply because people felt that there had not been an adequate
presentation of the need for the proposal.
In conclusion, he said he was recommending tabling of the M-Care
preference initiative, and asking for consideration of a Health System budget
that does not include M-Care preference.
Executive Vice President Matthews stated that he concurs with the
president's judgment. He observed that the Health System budget proposal
had gone through a number of iterations. The understanding had been that
there would be an attempt to build M-Care preference into the budget, but
obviously it would not be prudent to do that at this time. He observed that
the system had a "below the line" reserve and was not in dire straits, and
that although it would be appropriate to use the reserve under these
circumstances, in general, using the reserves is not a wise way to run an
enterprise over the long term. He noted that the reserves were built up
because the Hospitals had been prudent and successful in the past, and it
makes sense to take advantage of that. With that understanding, and with
the idea of working closely with the Hospitals in the coming year to go over
some of the broader issues affecting employees, the Hospitals would be able
to continue with its cost containment program.
Regent Maynard stated that she was comfortable with the decision. She
noted the excellent feedback that had been received from members of the
University community and wanted to be sure there would continue to be an
open discussion about these issues facing the Regents.
Regent McFee commented that she appreciated the efforts of the
Medical Center community in trying to address the economic issues facing
the health system. She cautioned that in tabling the issue to allow for
further discussion, it was important that the entire University recognize that
for a number of years the Medical Center had been a very profitable
enterprise, with much of it spilling over to the entire University. Now that
the reverse is the case, she believes the University as a whole should come
together to overcome the challenge facing the Medical Center and recognize
52




Special Meeting, August 1997


that we all have a responsibility to meet it. If, after further discussion, it
appears that the M-Care proposal will be a means to help balance the
Medical Center's budget, she thinks "we all should recognize that we need to
be part of that solution."
Regent Horning expressed agreement with Regent McFee's comments
and moved approval of the FY1998 University of Michigan Health System's
Clinical Delivery System Operating Budget. Regent Power seconded the
motion. Regents Deitch and Taylor also associated themselves with Regent
McFee's comments. The vote was then taken, and the motion was approved
unanimously.
There being no further business, the meeting was adjourned at 11:25 a.m.
Roberta R. Palmer
Secretary of the University

The University of Michigan

The Regents convened at 1:45 p.m. in the Regents' Room. Present were

Executive Vice President for Medical Affairs
President Bollinger announced that after having conducted an exhaustive
search, the clear choice that emerged to fill the position of executive vice
president for medical affairs was Gilbert S. Omenn, of the University of
Washington, and he reviewed Dr. Omenn's background and qualifications.
Regent McGowan moved approval of the appointment of Gilbert S. Omenn as
executive vice president for medical affairs. Regent Newman seconded the
motion, and it was approved unanimously. There followed a round of
applause, after which Dr. Omenn joined the Regents and officers at the table
and expressed how pleased he was to accept the appointment.  Regent

working with him.
Donald R. Shepherd Director of Intercollegiate Athletics
President Bollinger announced his recommendation for the appointment
of Thomas A. Goss as the Donald R. Shepherd Director of Intercollegiate
Athletics, noting that it was Mr. Goss's character and values that were most
important in his selection for this post. On a motion by Regent Newman,
seconded by Regent Taylor, the Regents unanimously approved the appointment
of Thomas A. Goss as the Donald R. Shepherd Director of Intercollegiate
Athletics.
Mr. Goss, who was present at the meeting, said that he was very excited
to be at Michigan, and that he shared the same values as President Bollinger
and the Regents. Regent Deitch commented on how lucky the University
was to have been able to attract two such accomplished individuals to fill key
appointments.
University of Michigan Financial Statements for Year-Ended
June 30, 1997
Referring to the separately bound consolidated financial statements,
Executive Vice President Matthews noted that the University had received a
clean opinion from its independent auditors, Ernst & Young LLP.


55




September Meeting, 1997


University of Michigan Year-End Financial Information for 1996-97
Executive Vice President Matthews called on Mr. Robert Moenart,
controller and director of financial operations, to review the year-end financial
information. Mr. Moenart compared how the various categories of funds,
revenues, expenditures, and endowments have changed over the past ten
years since 1987-88. Since that time, current funds educational and general
revenues have increased from $801 million to $1.472 million. The proportion
derived from state appropriations has decreased from 33 percent to 23
percent, while the portion derived from student fees has risen from 27
percent to 32 percent.
Auxiliary activities revenues have risen from $576 million in 1987-88 to
$1,174 in 1996-97, with the proportion attributed to hospital, medical, and
dental activities rising from about 84 percent to 87 percent. During that
time, total compensation expenditures have decreased from about 60 percent
of the Current Funds expenditures to 56 percent, and the proportion of that
expense attributed to staff benefits has increased. Expenditures for scholarships and fellowships have risen from 7 percent of the total to 10 percent of
the total. Provost Cantor observed that this figure reflects a change in institutional priorities, rather than an increase in demand.
Mr. Moenart noted that total auxiliary activities expenditures have been
generally flat over the past few years, and have been declining in the hospital
and medical area. The endowment and other invested funds have achieved a
10-year compound growth rate of 22.8 percent, after distributions of 5
percent. Investment in plant (including land, land improvements, buildings,
and equipment) has increased from $1.787 billion to $3.606 billion in the
past ten years.
Regent Power observed that corporate entities typically have a capital
budget separate from the operating budget, and he raised the question as to
whether this would be beneficial for the University to do as well. Executive
Vice President Matthews replied that the University does have a campus
plan, but that because of funding uncertainties, implementation of the plan
cannot always be done as intended. Regent Power reiterated that it may be
beneficial for the University to have a separate capital budget and requested
that some thought be given to this idea.
In response to a question from Regent Maynard about whether athletic
department revenues are ever funneled into the academic side of the institution, it was noted that all athletic department revenues stay within the
department and are used to fund it, although some of these funds are used to
support academic programs within the department. Vice President Harrison
pointed out that there is a "fire wall" between the athletic department and
the rest of the University such that funds are not exchanged between the two.
In conclusion, Mr. Moenart stated that the University's debt service as a
percentage of the operating expenditures has decreased, it is solvent, and is
in excellent shape financially.

the Regents' attention to the recommendations regarding Homer A. Neal,
vice president for research and former interim president. He noted that Vice
President Neal had decided to return to the faculty and work on the Atlas

post as interim vice president for research until such time as a permanent
replacement can be identified.

Retirement Memoirs. Provost Cantor submitted retirement memoirs
for 10 faculty members.
Joseph B. Adelson, professor of psychology in the College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts, retired from active status on May 31, 1997, following
more than 40 years of service.
Professor Adelson received his B.S. degree (1945) from the City College
of New York and his M.A. (1947) and Ph.D. (1950) degrees from the University
of California at Berkeley. He taught at Michigan State University (1950-51)
and Bennington College (1951-56) before joining the University of Michigan
faculty in 1956 as a visiting assistant professor of psychology. He was
promoted to assistant professor in 1957, associate professor in 1959, and
professor in 1963. He also held an appointment as senior psychologist at the
Psychological Clinic from 1956-87 and served as the director of this internship
training agency.
Throughout his career, Professor Adelson has focused on two areas:
adolescence and the psychological aspects of social and political issues. His
work has had a lasting influence, both within the social sciences and the
intellectual community as a whole. Many of his papers are classics: reframings
of key issues that have been supported and sustained by subsequent
research. Literally dozens of his papers have been reprinted in readers, in
some instances more than a dozen times. His book, Inventing Adolescence,
was named among the "Best Books of 1986" by the Chronicles of American
Culture, and it continues to be widely cited and respected, as does his earlier
book (with Elizabeth Douvan), The Adolescent Experience. Another of
Professor Adelson's notable and ongoing contributions has been as a book
reviewer of books for both professional and general audiences. His reviews
are a delight to read, not only informing readers but also teaching them.
Professor Adelson has held numerous research fellowships, has been the
recipient of many research and teaching awards, and has been a frequent
consultant to government organizations and foundations. He was the founding
editor of the journal Political Psychology and has been a consulting editor for
a number of major psychology journals, including the Merrill-Palmer
Quarterly, Journal of Personality and Social Psychology, Journal of Youth
and Adolescence, and Contemporary Psychology. He will long be remembered
by his colleagues and students for his broad intellect, his rich interest in the
arts and humanities, his tough-mindedness, his sense of humor, and his
graceful and elegant prose style.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Joseph B.
Adelson professor emeritus of psychology.
Robert T. Blackburn, professor of higher education, School of Education,
retired from active faculty status on June 30, 1997, following 31 years of
service.
Professor Blackburn received his B.S., M.S., and Ph.D. degrees, in 1947,
1948, and 1953, respectively, from the University of Chicago. Following military


92




September Meeting, 1997


service (1943-46), he was an assistant professor at Chico State College (1948-49);
director and assistant professor at George Williams College (1949-51);
research associate and instructor at the University of Chicago (1951-54);
assistant and associate professor at San Francisco State College (1954-58);
and member of the faculty, college examiner, and dean of faculty at Shimer
College (1958-66). He joined the University of Michigan School of Education
in 1966 as professor of higher education.
During his years in the School of Education and the Center for the
Study of Higher and Postsecondary Education, Professor Blackburn taught a
wide array of graduate courses and collaborated extensively with students,
both in research and publication. He served on the School of Education
Executive Committee a number of times, most recently from 1992-95, and
also served on many other School of Education and University-wide committees.
Professor Blackburn has also been an active member of FAIR (Faculty
Against Institutional Racism), a campus-wide faculty group.
Throughout his career, Professor Blackburn has maintained membership
in the American Education Research Association, the American Association
for Higher Education (AAHE), and the Association for the Study of Higher
Education (ASHE). He is past chair of the professors of higher education for
AAHE and regularly reviews articles for such journals as Higher Education,
Sociology of Education, and Review of Higher Education. He has worked on
a number of externally-funded research projects, has served as a consultant
to several colleges and universities, and is the author or co-author of numerous
publications (more than 100 since 1970). He is a member of the UM Faculty
Research Club and in 1988 became only the third person honored by the
ASHE with its Research Achievement Award.
The Regents now salute this faculty member for his dedicated service by
naming Robert T. Blackburn professor emeritus of higher education.
Dorothy E. Booth, assistant professor of nursing, retired from active
faculty status on September 1, 1997, following 10 years of dedicated service.
Professor Booth received her B.S.N. and M.S.N. degrees from Wayne
State University in 1972 and 1974, respectively, and her Ph.D. degree in
education from the University of Michigan in 1985. She is certified as a
gerontology nurse practitioner and has also earned certificates as a "Specialist
in Aging" from Harvard University (1978) and in "Interdisciplinary Geriatric
Education" from the University of Michigan (1984). She joined the University
of Michigan's School of Nursing as an assistant professor in 1987, following
eight years as an assistant professor at Wayne State University (1979-87). In
1995, she was also appointed as an associate fellow at the University of
Michigan's Institute of Gerontology.
Professor Booth has received multiple community and academic awards
in recognition of her devoted service to gerontological nursing education and
practice and to the community of elders. Following her retirement, she plans
to continue her collaborative research activities and will also work with the
School of Nursing's Office of Student Affairs to assist students of all levels in
the preparation of scholarly papers.


93




September Meeting, 1997


For her dedicated service and contributions to the University of Michigan,
the Regents now name Dorothy E. Booth assistant professor emerita of
nursing.
Dale A. Davis, associate professor of management and accounting
at the University of Michigan-Flint, retired from active faculty status on
May 31, 1997, after a most productive career as a teacher and researcher.
A native of Michigan, Professor Davis received his B.S. degree in
business administration in 1957 from Eastern Michigan University and his
M.B.A. and Ph.D. degrees in 1969 and 1978, respectively, from the University
of Michigan. From 1957-70, Professor Davis was a financial administrator
with Chevrolet Motor Division and from 1971-77, he was the academic
budget officer and a full-time instructor in accounting and finance at Eastern
Michigan University. In 1977, he moved to Volkswagen of America as the
corporate auditor and later as assistant controller at the Volkswagen
Westmoreland Assembly Plant. He joined the faculty of the University of
Michigan-Flint in 1982 as associate professor of management and accounting,
without tenure, and was awarded tenure in 1989.
Professor Davis' research has focused on the automotive area. He has
written approximately three-quarters of all the corporate procedures now in
place at Volkswagen of America, Inc., and his research culminated in the
basic financial analytical and reporting structure of the Volkswagen Foreign
Trade Zone in Westmoreland, Pennsylvania. He has appeared on television
as part of a network series on the world automotive industry and has
appeared locally to comment on domestic content legislation and the automobile
industry.
Professor Davis was awarded the Alpha Kappa Psi (professional
business fraternity) Outstanding Educator Award in 1973 and the University
of Michigan-Flint Excellence in Teaching Award in 1988-89. He has served
as president of the Beta Gamma Sigma Flint Chapter and is a member of the
accounting fraternity, Beta Alpha Psi. Professor Davis has also been
involved with the United Way of Detroit, served as an advisor for Junior
Achievement groups, was a fire commissioner in Ypsilanti Township, and
served as a volunteer probation officer for the 34th District Court in
Romulus, Michigan.
The Regents now salute this distinguished business educator for his
dedicated service by naming Dale A. Davis associate professor emeritus of
management and accounting.
John T. Headington, M.D., professor of pathology and professor of
dermatology in the Medical School, retired from active faculty status on
May 31, 1997.
Born in Grand Rapids, Dr. Headington was educated at the University
of Michigan, where he received his B.A. and M.D. degrees in 1952 and 1957,
respectively. After completing an internship at Virginia Mason Hospital in
Seattle in 1958, Dr. Headington returned to the University of Michigan for
residency training in anatomic and clinical pathology. In 1963-64, he was an
instructor in the Departments of Dermatology and Pathology at the University
of California in San Francisco. He returned to the University of Michigan in


94




September Meeting, 1997


1964 to accept an appointment as assistant professor of pathology. He was
promoted to associate professor of pathology and dermatology in 1968 and to
professor in 1971.
During his career, Dr. Headington was invited to present over 40
lectures internationally. He served as visiting professor of pathology at the
University of Illinois Chiang Mai Project in Chang Mai, Thailand, from 1966-68;
as visiting professor of pathology at the Groote Schuur Hospital in
Capetown, South Africa, in 1991, and was the recipient of a Wellcome
Research Travel Grant to the Dermatopathology Research Laboratories of
the Guys Hospital in London, England.
Dr. Headington is board certified in both anatomic and clinical pathology
as well as in dermatopathology and dermatology. He has been the institution's
premier dermatopathologist and has received numerous awards from the
Departments of Pathology and Dermatology, the Medical School, and national
and international organizations. Dr. Headington has been an active member
of numerous professional organizations, including having served as secretarytreasurer and as president of the American Society of Dermatopathology.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health educator for his
dedicated service by naming John T. Headington professor emeritus of
pathology and professor emeritus of dermatology.
Elliot Juni, professor of microbiology, retired from active faculty status
on August 31, 1997, following 31 years of service.
A native of New York City, Professor Juni received his B.E.E. degree in
1944 from the College of the City of New York and his Ph.D. degree in microbiology in 1951 from Western Reserve University. He joined the faculty of
the University of Illinois in 1951 and moved to Emory University in 1956 as
an associate professor. He was promoted to professor at Emory in 1965. He
joined the University of Michigan faculty as professor of microbiology in
1966.
Professor Juni is noted for his dedication to teaching and research in the
area of microbial metabolism. During his tenure at the University, Professor
Juni taught basic microbiology to medical students and microbial metabolism
to undergraduate and graduate students. He was a member of the editorial
board of the Journal of Bacteriology and was a member of the International
Committee on Systematic Bacteriology.
Professor Juni's research contributions have as their focus the elucidation
of metabolic pathways and the mechanism of genetic transformation, and the
use of genetic transformation and nutritional assays for the identification of
bacteria. He has devised a novel method of establishing the genetic relatedness
of bacteria in genera such as Acinetobacter, Moraxella, and Neisseria. He has
been recognized for his scientific contributions by having an organism named
after him-Acinetobacterjunii.
The Regents now salute this dedicated educator and researcher for his
contributions and service by naming Elliot Juni professor emeritus of
microbiology.
Edwin L. Miller, professor of business administration in the School of
Business Administration, retired from active faculty status on June 30, 1997.


95




September Meeting, 1997


Professor Miller received his B.A. and M.S. degrees from San Jose State
College in 1951 and 1957, respectively, and his Ph.D. degree from the
University of California in 1964. From 1960-63, he was an assistant professor
at San Jose State College. He joined the University of Michigan faculty in
1964 as an assistant professor and was promoted to associate professor in
1968 and professor in 1972. From 1986-93, he also served as associate dean
of the School of Business Administration.
Professor Miller has been an excellent teacher and faculty member. He
has been a central figure in the M.B.A. curriculum for many years and was
involved in the early design of the M.B.A. core curriculum. His involvement
in the beginnings of the school's Asia strategy and other internationalization
initiatives eventually led to such flagship programs as the M.B.A. domestic
corps, the M.B.A. Africa corps, and the Center for International Business
Education, among others. He also oversaw the development and growth of
the school's Division of Research, which now coordinates and guides the
many faculty research initiatives. Professor Miller's unwavering dedication
to the students and programs of the business school was an integral part of
the dean's administration for many years.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Edwin L. Miller
professor emeritus of business administration.
Georgine M. Steude, M.D., assistant professor of anesthesiology and
assistant professor of obstetrics and gynecology, retired from active faculty
status on August 31, 1997, after a long and productive career as a clinician,
teacher, and administrator.
Dr. Steude received her B.A. degree from Valparaiso University in 1953
and her M.D. degree from Northwestern University Medical School in 1957.
Dr. Steude received her internship and residency training in anesthesiology
at the University of Michigan from 1957-60. She was an instructor in
anesthesiology at the University of Michigan Medical Center from 1960-63
and from 1968-72. She was in private practice in Saline, Michigan, from
1963-68. She joined the University of Michigan faculty as an assistant
professor of anesthesiology in 1968.
In 1982, Dr. Steude was appointed assistant professor of obstetrics and
gynecology, and from 1983-89 she acted as section chief of obstetrical
anesthesiology. She also was section chief of pediatric anesthesiology from
1985-89. Dr. Steude served as interim chair of the Department of Anesthesiology from 1989-90.
In 1991, Dr. Steude took a sabbatical leave and gained additional
postgraduate training in pain management. She then returned to the department as a member of the Pain Management Section and the following year
became director of the Acute Pain Service. She continued seeing chronic
pain patients on a weekly basis while managing one of the larger acute pain
services in the nation. In 1994, she became board certified in the subspecialty
of pain management of anesthesiology. This was the first year that this
certification process was offered.
In addition to her extensive clinical and teaching responsibilities, Dr.
Steude has served on more than 40 committees at national, state, and institutional levels. She was president of the Michigan Society of Anesthesiologists


96




September Meeting, 1997


from 1990-92 and trustee of the Robert B. Sweet Memorial Fund from
1980-96.
The Regents now salute this distinguished medical educator for her
dedicated service by naming Georgine M. Steude assistant professor emerita
of anesthesiology and assistant professor emerita of obstetrics and
gynecology.
John W. Weigel II, librarian, retired from the University Library on
August 31, 1997, after more than 30 years of service.
A native of Pennsylvania, John (Jack) Weigel received his B.A. degree in
mathematics, summa cum laude, from Dickinson College in 1956, his M.A.
degree in physics from The Johns Hopkins University in 1960, and his M.S.
degree in library science from Columbia University in 1962. He joined the
University Library in 1964 as physics/astronomy/mathematics librarian.
Mr. Weigel's career at Michigan gives much evidence of his strong
commitment to the library's collections. From 1970-85, he edited the Union
List of Serials, an annual publication detailing the Library's holdings primarily
in the sciences and technology. In 1980, he was appointed to the study team
for the Collection Analysis Project, an intensive effort to examine the
patterns and practices of collection building in the library, and chaired its
Task Force on New Needs and Possibilities. Mr. Weigel also served as the
science and technology selector for the Graduate Library and as a regular
guest lecturer in the School of Information.
In the early 1980s, Mr. Weigel served as the library's personnel and staff
development officer. Later he was selected to help implement the library's
on-line public catalog, MIRLYN. In the past several years, Mr. Weigel served
as coordinator of Access Services and Collection Services for the Shapiro
Science Library. He was instrumental in ensuring the smooth operation of
the Science Library and of the moves from the separate locations into the
one library.
A recognized leader in science librarianship nationally, Mr. Weigel served
as president of the Michigan chapter of the Special Libraries Association
(SLA) and worked with colleagues from around the country to establish the
Physics/Astronomy/Mathematics Section of SLA Within the Research Libraries
Group, Mr. Weigel chaired its Committee on the Long Term Serials Project
for physics and was a member of its Committee for Mathematics.
Mr. Weigel's knowledge, sense of humor, and wise counsel have characterized his career at Michigan. He leaves with the sincere respect of his
colleagues for a job well done.
The Regents now salute this distinguished librarian by naming John W.
Weigel II librarian emeritus.
L. Yvonne Wulff, program director for international initiatives and
librarian, University Library, retired on August 29, 1997, after nearly 20
years of service.
A native of the Pacific Northwest, Ms. Wulff received her B.S. degree
from Washington State University in 1962 and her A.M.L.S. degree from the
University of Washington in 1963. She began her career at The Ohio State
University in 1963 and later served in the Seattle Public Library, the


97




September Meeting, 1997


University of Washington libraries, The Johns Hopkins medical institutions,
and the University of Minnesota Bio-Medical Library. In 1970, she completed
the course work for her Ph.D. degree in information transfer at Syracuse
University.
Ms. Wulff joined the University of Michigan in January 1978 as head of
the Medical Center Library. She had a comprehensive understanding of how
excellent medical libraries should be run and a strong devotion to providing
outstanding service. Ms. Wulff not only guided the growth and development
of the services and collections of the Medical Library, but also eventually
assumed responsibility for the other health sciences libraries, in public health
and dentistry.
In August 1987, Ms. Wulff was named assistant director for collection
management for the University Library. For six years, she led the transition
from collection development responsibility resting in a single individual to
the responsibility resting broadly with those who serve on the Collection
Management and Development Council (CMDC). Under her leadership,
CMDC became a vital advisory group for the Library's administration. In
1993, Ms. Wulff became the library's first program director for international
initiatives. Her work focused on building connections with the International
Institute and other international efforts on campus and on bringing more
Fulbright scholars to the library than at any time in the past.
Ms. Wulff is a critical thinker whose thoughtful comments and questions
often changed the course of discussion. She was committed to the well-being
of the library and made important contributions as the library moved into
the electronic world.
The Regents now salute this distinguished librarian by naming L. Yvonne
Wulff librarian emerita.

The University's Investments at June 30, 1997
Executive Vice President Matthews submitted a series of reports on the
University's invested funds. He called on Associate Vice President Norman
Herbert to review the report.
Associate Vice President Herbert noted that the University Endowment
Fund (UEF) grew from about $1.6 billion to almost $2 billion during the past
year, while providing $76.4 million in distributions for program support.
The Donor Pooled Income Fund grew from $8.1 million to $9.5 million, while
distributing over $350,000 to income beneficiaries.
Associate Vice President Herbert noted that the Long Term Portfolio's
return was 18 percent for the year. While strong in absolute terms, it trailed
the returns of the S&P and MSCI World Index, and he gave several explanations

September Meeting, 1997


for this. In contrast, the University Investment Pool and Veritas had returns
of 11.0 and 9.9 percent, well above the indices for short duration portfolios
which were used before making changes in the investment strategy for these
portfolios.

OCTOBER MEETING, 1997


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Friday, October 17, 1997
The Regents convened at 9:45 a.m. in the Regents' Room. Present were
President Bollinger and Regents Deitch, Horning, Maynard, McFee, McGowan,
Newman, Power, and Taylor. Also present were Interim Executive Vice
President Matthews, Provost Cantor, Vice President Harrison, Vice President
Hartford, Vice President Kinnear, Interim Vice President Neidhardt,
Chancellor Nelms, Chancellor Renick, Interim Co-General Counsel Barry,
and Secretary Palmer. Executive Vice President Omenn was absent.
External Audit Report
Executive Vice President Matthews noted that Ernst & Young LLP had
conducted the annual University audits for the year ended June 30, 1997,
and had issued a management letter. He called on Mr. Carl Smith, director
of University Audits, who introduced Mr. Robert Emde, of Ernst & Young.
Mr. Emde introduced his colleagues who helped conduct the audit: Mr.
George Johnson, Mr. Harold Miller, and Mr. Steve Staelin. He noted that
Mr. Staelin would succeed him in the role of coordinating partner responsible
for the firm's audit of the University's financial statements, beginning with
the 1997-98 audit.
Mr. Emde stated that the audit completed on August 8, 1997, expresses an
unqualified opinion on the University's financial statements. The accounting
principles and the magnitude and extent of year-end closing entries were
consistent with prior years, and there were no unadjusted differences that
would have had a material effect on the respective funds comprising the
financial statements for 1997. Audits were also conducted and reported on
the separate financial statements for the Clinical Delivery System, Dental
Faculty Associates, the Board in Control of Intercollegiate Athletics, the
Executive Education Center of the School of Business Administration,
M-Care, Veritas, the Alumni Association, the William Davidson Institute, and
the University Musical Society. Reports on each of these financial statements
are also unqualified.
Mr. Emde noted that the management letter states that a review of the
internal control structure disclosed no material weaknesses in procedures
and controls. He pointed out that the recommendations set forth in the
management letter are intended as constructive suggestions to further
strengthen the University's procedures and controls. In each instance, the
University has concurred with the recommendation, and Ernst & Young
believes the University's responses are appropriate. He also noted that
appropriate actions have been taken with respect to each recommendation in
the 1996 management letter.


107




October Meeting, 1997


Regent McFee commented that she was particularly pleased to note that
the University is especially careful in its oversight of reports from its custodian
bank in connection with its alternative investments.
Regent Power said that he hopes that the question of whether the
University should generate a capital budget will be addressed in the near
future, both in terms of internal practice and in terms of recommendations
from independent auditors. He noted that although capital budgets had not
been drawn up in the past, the University's cash flow and capacity to issue
paper have reached the point at which it can internally control capital activities
to a far greater extent than was possible previously. He expressed the hope
that Ernst & Young would be helpful to the new executive vice president and
chief financial officer and other staff in addressing this issue.
Regent Taylor requested that the Regents receive regular progress
reports and a schedule describing how the University is addressing the "Year
2000 Problem." Mr. Matthews responded that this can certainly be done.
He noted that this is not only a problem for the University's own internal
systems, but also for its vendors and others who deal with the University.
Regent Taylor also requested to see the letter that had been sent to the
University's vendors and suppliers requesting information about how they
were dealing with this problem, as well as the list of the letter's recipients.
Regent Power indicated that the Board does not have an audit committee,
and therefore he would encourage the auditors to discuss any matters of
concern with any member of the Board. Mr. Emde responded that there was
nothing at this time that needed to be discussed with the Board, other than
in public session.
Consent Agenda
Minutes. Secretary Palmer submitted the minutes of the September
1997 meeting.
Reports. Executive Vice President Matthews submitted Reports of
Investment, Plant Extension, Litigation, Human Resources and Affirmative
Action, and Non-Competitive Purchases over $5,000 from Single Sources from
July 1 through September 30, 1997. He noted that the August investment
performance highlights how a diversified portfolio benefits the institution.
He called on Associate Vice President Herbert, who gave a report highlighting
the August performance of investments. Mr. Herbert pointed out that
despite the world-wide weakness in financial markets, the University's Long
Term Portfolio had performed well, with all of its stock and bond managers
outperforming their respective benchmarks and adding value to their
portfolios.
Regarding the Plant Extension Report, Regent Newman asked that
future reports also include the names of the architect under the "architect
appointed" section of the report.


108




October Meeting, 1997


Vice President Neidhardt submitted a report on projects established for
September 1997.
Voluntary Support. Vice President Kinnear submitted a report of
voluntary support. Regent Newman asked whether the University would be
responding to a challenge made by Ira Harris at the recent Campaign for
Michigan celebration to increase the campaign goal to $2 billion by the year
2000. Mr. Harris had offered to make an additional gift of $2 million to
begin a new drive. Vice President Kinnear noted that the $2 billion figure
will probably be approached in the general course of donor solicitation, but
whether or not the University is still involved in an official fundraising
campaign is a different issue.
President Bollinger noted that while the University is very appreciative
of Mr. Harris' support of the institution, the general issue of whether to
pursue a capital campaign raises complex institutional issues that need to be
carefully considered. It is best to consider the recent Campaign for Michigan
as completed. However, Mr. Harris' generosity is greatly appreciated.

October Meeting, 1997


Richard F. de Leon, associate dean for clinical sciences and associate
professor of pharmacy, College of Pharmacy, and director of pharmacy
services, University of Michigan Health Systems, retired from active faculty
status on September 30, 1997.
Professor de Leon received an A.A. degree from the City College of San
Francisco in 1961 and a Pharm.D. degree from the University of California
at San Francisco in 1965. He holds pharmacy licenses in both California and
Michigan. He began his career as an intern pharmacist at the University of
California-San Francisco Department of Pharmaceutical Services in 1961.
By 1978, he had risen through the ranks to positions as director of central
services and assistant dean for pharmaceutical services.
In 1979, Professor de Leon came to the University of Michigan as associate
dean for clinical sciences and associate professor, College of Pharmacy, and
as director of pharmacy services, University of Michigan Hospitals. His
responsibilities included managing the operations of the Department of
Pharmacy Services and overseeing the clinical sciences program, including
the experiential training program at the college. He also assumed responsibility
for directing the college's continuing education program in 1993.
He has served on numerous local and national committees and has
presented a number of invited seminars at national and international
meetings. He has provided consultative services to many outside organizations
and has served as an accreditation reviewer for the American Society of
Health System Pharmacists and for the American Council on Pharmaceutical
Education.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health educator and administrator for his dedicated service by naming Richard F. de Leon associate professor
emeritus of pharmacy.
Donald F. Huelke, professor of anatomy in the Medical School and
research scientist at the University of Michigan Transportation Research
Institute, retired from active faculty status on August 31, 1997.
Professor Huelke received his B.S. (1952) and M.S. (1954) degrees from
the University of Illinois and his Ph.D. (1957) degree in anatomy from the
University of Michigan. He joined the University of Michigan faculty in 1957
as an instructor in the Department of Anatomy. He was promoted to assistant
professor in 1960, associate professor in 1963, and professor in 1968. In
1983, he was appointed research scientist at the University of Michigan
Transportation Research Institute (UMTRI).
Professor Huelke's discipline is human gross anatomy. Very early in his
career, he became interested in applied biomechanics as it relates to motor
vehicle design and injuries from automobile accidents. His research resulted
in his being appointed to the Ad Hoc Faculty Program Advisory Committee
for the Highway Safety Research Institute in 1965. He served on the institute's
executive committee from 1967-86 and as interim director of the UMTRI
Biosciences Division in 1985 and 1986. During the 1960s, he conducted some
very influential studies on the causes of fatal injuries in automobile accidents
which had a significant impact on seat belt design and legislation. His
research on automobile safety has since expanded to include airbags.


127




October Meeting, 1997


In addition to his laboratory and field research, Professor Huelke taught
gross anatomy to medical and dental students. He also completed a three-part
history of the Department of Anatomy, which has proven to be a very valuable
piece of scholarly research and a major historical resource.
In 1980, Professor Huelke received the Ralph H. Isbrandt Automotive
Safety Engineering Award from the Society of Automotive Engineers. He
has also been honored as a fellow of the SAE and of the American Academy
of Forensic Sciences. He is a past president of the Association for the
Advancement of Automotive Medicine and has served for 20 years on the
Stapp Car Crash Conference Advisory Committee.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his
dedicated service by naming Donald F. Huelke professor emeritus of
anatomy and research scientist emeritus.
Nathaniel H. Rowe, Jr., D.D.S., William R. Mann Professor of
Dentistry and professor of dentistry in the School of Dentistry, and professor
of oral pathology, Department of Pathology, Medical School, will retire from
active faculty status on October 15, 1997.
Born in Hibbing, Minnesota, Dr. Row received his B.S. and D.D.S.
degrees in 1955 and his M.S.D. degree in 1958 from the University of Minnesota.
He joined the University of Michigan faculty as professor of dentistry in 1968
and was appointed associate professor of pathology in the Medical School in
1969. He also served as associate director of the Dental Research Institute in
the School of Dentistry from 1970-89. He was named a fellow of the American
Academy of Oral Pathology in 1959 and diplomate of the American Board of
Oral Pathology in 1964.
Dr. Rowe has distinguished himself nationally and internationally as a
dental scholar, researcher, and teacher. He has served as a consultant to
many governmental and professional organizations and has published more
than 60 journal articles and 10 textbook chapters.
Dr. Rowe served on the University's Senate Assembly from 1975-78 and
from 1978-81 and on the School of Dentistry Executive Committee from
1973-76 and from 1977-80. He was president of the Science Research Club
from 1988-89. He is a member of the American Dental Association, the
American Association for Oral Pathology, International Academy of Pathology,
the International Association for Dental Research, Michigan Society of
Pathologists, the Royal Society of Health (England), and the International
Society for Antiviral Research. He served as a member of several Michigan
and national committees in affiliation with the American Cancer Society, the
Michigan Department of Public Health, and the State of Michigan. Dr. Rowe
is a member of Sigma Xi and Omicron Kappa Upsilon honorary societies. In
recognition of his outstanding intellectual leadership and nationally recognized
achievement in research, teaching, and service, in 1994 he was named the
first William R. Mann Professor of Dentistry at the University of Michigan.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health sciences educator by
naming Nathaniel H. Rowe, Jr., professor emeritus of dentistry, William R.
Mann Professor Emeritus of Dentistry and professor emeritus of oral
pathology.

Gilbert R. Whitaker, Jr., provost and executive vice president emeritus
for academic affairs, dean emeritus, and professor of business economics in
the School of Business Administration, retired from active faculty status on
August 31, 1997.
Professor Whitaker received his B.A. degree from Rice University in
1953 and his M.S. and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Wisconsin in
1958 and 1961, respectively. He served on the faculty at Northwestern
University (1960-66), Washington University (1967-76, including service as
associate dean from 1969-76), and Texas Christian University (professor and
dean from 1976-78) before joining the University of Michigan School of
Business Administration as dean and professor of business economics in
1979. He served with distinction as professor and dean until 1990, when he
was appointed provost and vice president for academic affairs.
Professor Whitaker's dedication to the excellence of students and
programs at the business school was the foundation for the growth and
success the school now enjoys. He laid the groundwork for the school's
prominence and readiness to maintain a leadership position into the twentyfirst century.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Gilbert R.
Whitaker, Jr., professor emeritus of business economics.

Affirmative Action Lawsuit
President Bollinger announced that a lawsuit has been filed against the
University of Michigan Ann Arbor Campus claiming that its admissions
policy is unconstitutional under the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution. He observed that "what is being attacked here is a long-standing policy
of the University of Michigan, which is deeply rooted in the history, traditions,
and identity of the University."
He noted that the University's diversity policy is similar to that of every
major institution of higher education in the country, and that this lawsuit is
part of a nation-wide effort by some groups to try to change those policies.
President Bollinger commented that "we view this with the gravest possible
concern." He noted the recent success of this movement in the Fifth Circuit
with respect to the Hopwood litigation involving the University of Texas, and
the success of the movement within the state of California in the form of a
referendum. He said the resulting situations represent clear proof of what
the University will face if the suit against it is successful.
President Bollinger said that the University has hired the law firm of
Wilmer, Cutler, & Pickering from Washington, D.C. as its counsel, and that
it is in the process of creating an answer to the complaint. He said that he
and Provost Cantor have been talking about how to facilitate the campus
discussion about these issues during the coming months. Announcements will
be forthcoming in the next few weeks about beginning efforts to address
these issues in various formats and platforms. The intent is to approach it
not only as a litigation issue, but also from the perspective of an educational
institution that must come to terms with these issues as an educational issue
as well.
President Bollinger concluded that "this will be a very difficult time for the
University of Michigan" and "it will be a test of our character as an institution
as to how we deal with it." He said "we must be open to discussion about this,"
while at the same time recognizing that historically, the institution has made
sure it has been open to all parts of American society, offering an experience
to students that is "as rich and diverse as we possibly can make it."

The Regents heard comments from Tom Stroup, alumnus, about the
termination of Michigan men's basketball coach, Steve Fisher.
There followed a five-minute break, at 10:55 a.m., after which the

Provost Cantor: Budget Strategies
Provost Cantor observed that the purpose of budgets is to support the
academic commitments of faculty and students. She noted that budgets affect
three domains: the local academic neighborhood; the collaborative academic
neighborhood; and the University as a whole, and discussed how the current
budgeting system, Value Centered Management (VCM), impacts each of these
domains.
She noted that VCM works well at the local level, providing incentives to
reduce costs and enhance revenue.    However, in the collaborative and
University-as-a-whole domains, VCM is more problematic, and it is in these
areas that she is proposing changes in the budgeting system. These changes
include first, changing the name from "Value Centered Management" to simply
our "budget model," to denote the University's system of resource allocation.
Provost Cantor noted that the University has to ensure that activities and
units that are not easily self-supporting are attended to, and it also has to be
attentive to the question of collaborative teaching and research activities. With
VCM, she pointed out, the incentives are at the local level, making it more difficult to accomplish collaborative activities. Likewise, because tuition follows
student enrollment, there are no incentives to teach students in a school other
than the one they are enrolled in. There also needs to be a means of support for
"public goods," such as museums, libraries, auditoriums, recreational sports,


136




November Meeting, 1997


etc., that help to support the University's overall reputation. The support of
public goods can be addressed by using resources at the provost's disposal to
ensure that public goods are supported, and by rewarding local units that
contribute to the public goods of the University as a whole and penalizing units
that are excessively inward looking with respect to the resources that they
control. Lastly, moving to a multi-year budgeting system for the provost's
allocation will allow both the administration and the units to determine what is
and is not self-supporting and to target activities that are priorities for support.
Provost Cantor observed that a current focus of discussion is cost attributions for central service resources and units. In the current model, cost attributions for central services are allocated according to 24 complicated formulas.
Thus the attention is being paid not to the missions of these central units and
how they should be tailored, but rather attention is being paid to whether the
other units are getting their own money's worth from the central units. The
issue of cost attributions for central services should be tackled not by focusing on
individual levels of subsidization, but rather by analyzing the unit as a whole to
see whether the University is getting what it needs from that unit (whether it is
rightly budgeted).  Therefore, Provost Cantor said she will take back the
revenues and cost attributions for these central service units to create the right
budgets for them and to evaluate their missions. She noted that these reviews
will be conducted in conjunction with the Advisory Committee on University
Budgets and described the process that will be used. Following these reviews, it
is expected that significant savings will be realized. These savings will be reallocated to the kinds of collaborative, public goods, non-self-supporting but valued
activities that are critical to the institution. She pointed out that the incentives
rest clearly with the administration to realize savings, as the only alternative, to
raise taxes on the schools and colleges, would be unacceptable.
FY99 State Budget Request - Ann Arbor Campus
Provost Cantor noted that the final aspect to the University's budgeting
process is the critical contribution of state support. She said that the University
is very grateful for the recent increases in state support that have exceeded inflation, as these have been important in limiting tuition increases. She also
expressed appreciation for recent actions on the capital outlay bill, which will
lead to renovations of some of the older central campus buildings.
The Ann Arbor campus is requesting an increase of 4 percent ($12.6
million) in its base appropriations from the state. In addition to this basic
increase, the state is being asked to join in a partnership with the University
to fund two specific initiatives: $1.5 million for expansion of Undergraduate
Learning Communities, and $3 million for a Life Sciences Initiative. The former
will create opportunities for smaller community experiences within the larger
university, and the latter will promote more activity in emerging interdisciplinary areas of life sciences education and research.
In response to a question from Regent Newman, Provost Cantor noted
that the main change proposed for the budget model is to centralize the
budget for central service units. Currently, cost attributions for these units


137




November Meeting, 1997


are distributed among the schools and colleges. In the proposed budget
model, an amount equivalent to the funds that schools would have used to
pay for the cost attributions will come back to the provost for review and
reallocation of these expenditures. This would presumably result in savings
that can be used to support collaborative and public goods activities and to
continue to keep tuition increases to a minimum.
Regent Power observed that any budgeting system that places what
appears to be arbitrary power in the hands of a provost offers risk. Provost
Cantor responded that she believes the proposed budgeting system places less
arbitrary power in the hands of the provost because of the incentives it provides
for holding down costs. It also provides incentives for interdisciplinary collaboration. Regent Power expressed the desire to revisit this topic periodically.
Regent Maynard commented that she was pleased that the administration
is paying particular attention to the effect of the budgeting system on interdisciplinary collaboration. Regent McFee agreed and also commended the
provost and her team for recognizing that no budget system is perfect and
for being willing to make changes in the system as experience dictates.
1998-99 State Budget Request - University of Michigan-Flint
Vice Chancellor Russell reported that UM-Flint is requesting an
increase of $2.5 million. This includes $800,000 as an inflationary increase
for basic operation of the campus and $1.0 million to support three initiatives
designed to enhance the economic revitalization of the Flint area. These
initiatives include Urban Education Initiatives, the Center for Applied
Environmental Research and Outreach, and the development of the former
AutoWorld site. The remainder of the requested appropriations increase
includes $300,000 to support new graduate program development and $400,000
for ongoing information technology needs.

technology enhancement; and $699,000 for faculty to support program growth.
