structure of bylaws. Regent McFee suggested the Bylaws revision as a topic
of discussion for the January meeting.
Regent Taylor noted that it might be useful to first clean up the current
Bylaws and then address the larger issues raised by Regent Power. General
Counsel Barry agreed that this would be a good approach.
Michigan Student Assembly Report
Mr. Michael Nagrant, president of the Michigan Student Assembly
(MSA), began by stating that contrary to media reports, MSA had not
endorsed rushing of the field by students following the upcoming football
game against Ohio State University.
Mr. Nagrant reviewed the goals he had set out at his first meeting with
the Regents. These included a request that tuition increases be limited to
the rate of inflation, consideration of the need for a student Regent, and an
MSA fee increase. He thanked the Board for limiting the tuition increase for
1997-98 and for approving the MSA fee increase. He noted that since he had
assumed the MSA presidency, MSA had returned almost $13,000 to student
groups through internal cost savings, had organized a campus-wide affirmative
action issues forum, had helped to organize the environmental theme semester,
had funded over $60,000 in community service initiatives for the first time,
and was set to begin operating a nonprofit course-pack store.
Mr. Nagrant said that MSA is proposing three new initiatives: extending
hours in the graduate and law libraries; establishing a break in the fall
semester; and establishing an endowed speaker series.
Following Mr. Nagrant's presentation, President Bollinger and the Regents
expressed support for the notion of extending the library hours and for
establishing better access for students to the rich array of speakers that is


139




November Meeting, 1997


already available on campus. Regent Newman observed that one of the
founders of C-SPAN, John Evans, is a major donor and suggested that he be
approached with the idea of establishing a television network that would
broadcast lectures and speeches made on campus.
Student Housing Issues
Regent Newman said that for some time, she had been requesting a
thorough review of the housing situation on campus and all of the issues that
encompasses, such as the size of the freshman class, privatization of
residence halls and services, and possible new residence hall construction.
She noted that it had been announced recently that there would be a lottery
next year for residence hall slots for junior and senior students.  She
observed that it is important for students to live in environments conducive
to academics, and that with the current overcrowded situation in the
residence halls, there is no room to accommodate proposed living-learning
communities.
There followed a discussion about the current utilization of the
residence halls. It was noted that for next year, there is a proposal to have
juniors and senior who want to live in residence halls be assigned to the
"nontraditional" halls, leaving the "traditional" residence halls for first and
second year students.
Regent Taylor observed that it would be helpful to survey students to
determine what percentage would like to live in residence halls if they had
the option. Regent Maynard pointed out that the desire to live in residence
halls is cyclical. There have been times in the past when residence halls were
not filled to capacity because students did not want to live there. Vice President Hartford stated that she would be prepared at the next meeting to
report on the residence hall situation for next year.
Executive Session Motion
Regent Power made the following motion:
Pursuant to Section 8(e) of the Open Meetings Act, as amended by
1984 PA 202 and 1996 PA 464, I move that the Board of Regents meet
in closed session on November 20, 1997, in the Regents' Room, for the
purpose of consulting with our attorney regarding trial or settlement
strategy in connection with specific pending litigation.
Regent McFee seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
The meeting then recessed at 3:30 p.m. and resumed shortly thereafter in
executive session.
Friday, November 21, 1997
The Regents convened at 9:45 a.m. in the Regents' Room. Present were
President Bollinger and Regents Deitch, Homing, Maynard, McFee,
McGowan, Newman, Power, and Taylor. Also present were Interim Executive


140




November Meeting, 1997


Vice President Matthews, Executive Vice President Kasdin, Provost and
Executive Vice President Cantor, Vice President Harrison, Vice President
Hartford, Vice President Kinnear, Interim Vice President Neidhardt,
Chancellor Renick, Interim Co-General Counsel Barry, and Secretary Palmer.
Chancellor Nelms was absent; Vice Chancellor Dorothy Russell attended in
his stead. Executive Vice President Omenn arrived shortly after the start of
the meeting.
Michigan Stadium Expansion
President Bollinger called on Mr. Tom Goss, director of intercollegiate
athletics, to present a proposal for expansion of the Michigan Stadium. Mr.
Goss noted that due to the fact that nearly 3,000 freshmen students were
unable to obtain season football tickets, and that there is a 98.5 percent
renewal rate for season ticket holders with a long waiting list of potential
season ticket buyers, it is important that the stadium capacity situation be
addressed before the 1998 season. He also pointed out that the University's
schedule of prominent opponents nearly guarantees that each season will
continue to be a sellout, even with the proposed addition of approximately
5,000 seats.
Mr. Goss noted that pending approval by the Regents, plans are to have
the addition completed by the start of the 1998 season. During construction,
commencement will still be able to occur in the stadium in the spring.
Regent McGowan noted that she had expressed concerns about the issue
of holding commencement in the stadium during construction, and about
how the project would be paid for if attendance projections did not
materialize. Executive Vice President Matthews had responded to her concerns
in a letter, and Regent McGowan requested that this response be incorporated
in the minutes of this meeting. The text of that letter can be found in the
Appendix.
Regent Horning stated that although he supports the expansion
proposal, at some point the season ticket situation should be addressed. He
noted that there are corporate entities and individuals who hold large blocks
of season tickets, and this raises the more general question of access to
season tickets. Mr. Goss responded that a task force has been formed to
examine the question of season ticket distribution. His goal is to have this
project completed before season ticket applications for the 1998 season are
mailed in May 1998.
Regent Newman asked whether there are plans to address the press box
situation. Mr. Goss responded that this would be addressed at some point,
but that the timing will be a matter of priorities and financing. Regent
Power requested that in the event that sky boxes ever become a consideration,
the issue should be brought to the Board for discussion.
Regent Horning moved approval of proceeding with the design and
construction of a project to increase the seating capacity of the stadium, as


141




November Meeting, 1997


described in the Regents Communication. Regent Newman seconded the
motion.
President Bollinger called on Mr. Fred Mayer, who presented the
proposed design. Mr. Mayer displayed historical photographs and reviewed
the history of the stadium, noting that seating capacity had been increased
three times since the structure's initial completion in 1927. Using diagrams
of the current stadium configuration, he indicated where the proposed
additional rows of seating, which would increase the capacity by about 5,000
seats, would be located.
Mr. Mayer noted that the firm of Venturi, Scott Brown and Associates,
Inc., had been retained to advise the University on planning and design
issues, and that the firm had been consulted on the design of the proposed
stadium addition. He displayed sketches of the firm's concept for the
addition. The firm's approach is to enliven the stadium and provide an
atmosphere that expresses the vitality and excitement that occurs during
athletic events, which it believes is particularly appropriate for an entertainment venue such as the stadium.
Following the presentation, the Regents expressed enthusiasm for the
design. President Bollinger distributed a memorandum from Venturi, Scott
Brown and Associates describing their design concept. Mr. Goss stated that
if the design is approved, plans are to have a groundbreaking ceremony at
the stadium before the football game the next day. The vote was then taken,
and the motion was approved unanimously.
Consent Agenda
Minutes. Secretary Palmer submitted minutes of the October 17, 1997,
meeting.
Reports. Interim Executive Vice President Matthews submitted the
following reports: Investment, Plant Extension, Litigation, and Human
Resources and Affirmative Action. He called on Associate Vice President
Norman Herbert to comment about the investment report. Mr. Herbert
updated the Board about how the Long Term Portfolio had fared following
events on October 27, 1997, when the stock market experienced the largest
one-day drop since 1987. He said he believes that although the portfolio will
have decreased by slightly less than 3.0 percent, this performance is positive
compared to the performance of the major comparative indices and unofficial
estimates of the performance of the top 25 institutions. He described how
each aspect of the portfolio contributed to this performance.
Executive Vice President Matthews noted that the names of the project
architects have been added to the Plant Extension report.
Vice President Neidhardt submitted a report of projects established during
October 1997. He also noted that due to the University's reputation with respect
to dealing with research integrity issues, the U.S. Public Health Service Office of


142




November Meeting, 1997


Research Integrity has invited the University to cosponsor a program on managing integrity in research. This will take place February 10 and 11, 1998.
Medical Affairs Report. Executive Vice President Omenn reported
that a patent had recently been issued to the University of Michigan for
pioneering gene transfer technology developed in the 1980s at the Medical
School, and the University plans to develop a non-exclusive licensing strategy
to make patent claims available to all for-profit corporations currently using
the technology. He announced that a Center for Gene Therapy has recently
been established by the UM Health System. This program will enhance the
basic sciences and the technological infrastructure for doing gene therapy
research and exploring potential applications.
Executive Vice President Omenn also announced that efforts are underway to increase the University's activity in the area of intellectual property,
licensing, royalties, etc. He noted that developing the gene transfer technology represents a significant challenge for all involved.
Executive Vice President Omenn listed the following major medical
school research initiatives undertaken within the health system in recent
months: 1) Biomedical Sciences Scholars, which is an effort to recruit
leaders in biomedical research; 2) Center for Gene Therapy, meant to
enhance genetic research; 3) Center for Organogenesis, for research on
embryo development and birth defects; 4) Health Services Research Initiative, to study the outcomes of medical care and all aspects of system performance; 5) Basic Sciences Integration, an effort by the six science departments
in the Medical School to consolidate some aspects of these departments,
aimed at attracting top students.
Voluntary Support. Vice President Kinnear submitted the report of
voluntary support for October 1997 and noted that voluntary support is
currently ahead of last year's record. He distributed a handout documenting
the total of $1,415,162,693 received in the Campaign for Michigan. The
beneficiaries of the campaign are students (through scholarships and
programs) and faculty (through more endowed chairs). He noted that more
than 250,000 individuals had contributed to the campaign.
Vice President Kinnear thanked the Regents, presidents, provosts, vice
presidents, and deans who had been involved in the campaign, as well as the
Office of Development staff, for contributing to its success. He also noted
that as a matter of course, the totals should reach $2.0 billion by 2000, but
this would not occur in the context of a campaign.

Retirement Memoirs. Provost Cantor submitted one retirement memoir.
Jack W. Meiland, professor of philosophy in the College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts, retired from active faculty status on August 31, 1997,
following 35 years of service.
Professor Meiland received his B.A. (1956), M.A. (1957), and Ph.D
(1962) degrees from the University of Chicago. He joined the University of
Michigan faculty in 1962 as an instructor of philosophy. He was promoted to
assistant professor in 1964, associate professor in 1968, and professor in
1974.   Professor Meiland also served as director of the LS&A           Honors
Program   from  1979-83, as LS&A's associate dean for long-range planning
and curriculum from 1983-90, and as associate dean for undergraduate
education from 1990-92.


158




November Meeting, 1997


Professor Meiland's philosophical interests have been unusually wideranging, including metaphysics, epistemology, philosophy of mind, philosophy
of logic, philosophy of the social sciences and of history, phenomenology,
hermeneutics, contemporary continental philosophy, and American philosophy
and pragmatism. He has published three influential books in these areas:
Scepticism and Historical Knowledge (1965), The Nature of Intention (1970),
and Talking About Particulars (1970). He has also published thirty articles,
and is co-editor, with Michael Krauss, of Relativism: Cognitive and Moral
(1982).
In recognition of his outstanding contributions to undergraduate education,
Professor Meiland was appointed Arthur F. Thurnau Professor in 1988, and
twice received the LS&A Excellence in Education Award. A superb classroom
teacher, he is known for his caring approach to students; he teaches without
pretense, conveying to students that he is a partner in learning. He taught
classes in the Residential College and in the Inteflex Program, and had a
special talent for making philosophy come alive for students whose chief
interests lie elsewhere. In the last few years, Professor Meiland reintroduced
American philosophy into the curriculum, and developed two new courses:
"Great Books in Philosophy," and "Science, Culture, and Values." For many
years, Professor Meiland taught a University Division course of his own
design for first-year students, "Methods of Thinking."  His book, College
Thinking (1981), is one of the few college guides that discusses how to
benefit intellectually from college.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming
Jack W. Meiland professor emeritus of philosophy.
Memorial.    Provost Cantor noted the death of Professor Roy
Rappaport. She observed that Professor Rappaport was a world-renowned
anthropologist who had also been an extraordinary citizen of the University.
The Regents of the University of Michigan acknowledge with profound
sadness the death on October 9, 1997, of Roy A. ("Skip") Rappaport, the
Leslie A. White Professor of Anthropology. Professor Rappaport died at
home at the age of 71 after a period of prolonged illness, under the loving
care of his wife, Ann Hart Rappaport, and his daughters, Amelia and Gina.
Honored this year with the University's Distinguished Faculty Achievement
Award, Professor Rappaport was recognized internationally as a major figure
in anthropology. Skip Rappaport was broadly trained at Columbia, receiving
his Ph.D. in 1966. (Anthropology was his second career; his first had been as
an innkeeper.) His main contributions have been in the areas of ecological
anthropology, the anthropology of religion, the anthropology of the Pacific,
specifically Papua-New Guinea, and, most recently, applied or "engaged"
anthropology.
Rappaport has written three books, and a fourth, Holiness and Humanity,
will be published posthumously. His Pigs for the Ancestors: Ritual in the
Ecology of a New Guinea People (1967) is the most important and widelycited book ever published in the field of ecological anthropology. It is considered
a major work of theory, yet it is also empirically grounded in his meticulous
collection of quantitative and qualitative data on such "material" matters as


159




November Meeting, 1997


diet and energy expenditure, as well as such mental-cognitive-ideational
domains as myth and folk taxonomies. The analysis of ritual that emerged
from this field research among the Tsembaga Maring of Papua-New Guinea
was developed and elaborated in several essays on ritual and religion, many
of them collected in his Ecology, Meaning, and Religion (1979).
Professor Rappaport was a man of huge erudition, relentlessly intellectual,
concerned with knowledge, theory, facts, ideas, and also social policy. His
recent work links with what is usually called "applied" or "practical" anthropology, but which Rappaport preferred to call "engaged anthropology." As president of the American Anthropological Association, he directed anthropology
toward policy issues and engagement with social problems. He also contributed
directly to policy through his consulting work on the social impact of outer
continental oil drilling and nuclear waste disposal.
For his former students, Skip Rappaport was generous, supportive, and
encouraging, serving as an ideal scholarly mentor. His teaching activity and
initiatives spanned the University curriculum from Anthropology 101 to upperlevel theory courses and two theme semesters. Generations of graduate and
undergraduate students at Michigan have learned about the anthropology of
religion from Professor Rappaport. His recently completed book manuscript,
Holiness and Humanity, a contribution to anthropological theory and to
religious studies, evolved as he has taught, developed, and revised this course
over the years.
Professor Rappaport served the University as two-term chair of the
anthropology department, and, much more recently, as head of the Program
on Studies in Religion. He has been a member of the LSA executive committee
and the University Senate Assembly. Nationally he served four years as
president-elect and then president of the American Anthropological Association.
Professor Rappaport served on committees, panels, and boards too numerous
to name. In recognition of his teaching, research, and service, Skip was
named to a Walgreen Chair and elected to the American Academy of Arts
and Sciences. As we mourn the loss of this great scholar and public servant,
our condolences go to his wife, Ann, and his daughters, Amelia and Gina.
Honorary Degrees. President Bollinger submitted the names of three

commencement: Gwendolyn Calvert Baker, former president and CEO, U.S.
Committee for UNICEF (Doctor of Laws); Ken Burns, Filmmaker and historian (Doctor of Laws); and Richard E. Smalley, Nobel-Prize-winning chemist
(Doctor of Science).
Regent McGowan stated that she was delighted to learn of the recommendation regarding Ken Burns, noting that it is significant that the University is recognizing through its honorary degree process the distinguished
career of a person at a younger age than has been customary in the past.

Proposed License Agreement between the University of Michigan
and IntraLase Corporation
Vice President Neidhardt pointed out that this action request concerns
IntraLase Corporation, not IntraLase, Inc., as stated in the Regents
Communication.
Regent Power moved approval of a license agreement between the
University of Michigan and IntraLase Corporation. Because Ron Kurtz and
Tibor Juhasz are both University employees and holders of equity interest in
IntraLase, this license agreement falls under the state of Michigan Conflict
of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance
with statutory requirements:


162




November Meeting, 1997


1.   Parties to the agreement are the University of Michigan and IntraLase
Corporation ("IntraLase").
2.   The terms of the contract are that the contracts to be completed between
the University and IntraLase include the license to be executed as well as
documents covering stock transfers and related matters. A sponsored
research contract between the University and IntraLase will be the subject
of a separate Regental Action Request.
The license will provide IntraLase with exclusive rights to the technology
for the field of laser medical instruments. The University will retain ownership of the technology, internal research use rights, the right to convey the
standard governmental license, and commercialization rights in fields
outside of the field granted exclusively to IntraLase.
The University will receive a royalty of 1.5% to 2.5% (depending upon the
patentability of the incorporated technology) of all net sales of products of
IntraLase and its sublicensees. The University will also receive modest
minimum annual royalties beginning in 1999, starting at $5,000 per year
and increasing to $15,000 per year.
The license will require that IntraLase secure at least $1,000,000 in outside
funding for the company's development activities by February 28, 1999.
Once that funding has been obtained, the University will receive equity in
the company under a separate agreement. The equity position will be a
minority position (giving the University 25% of the pool of company stock
which remains after subtracting all shares issued to new cash investors and
issued under corporate management plans to officers from the total of all
shares of company stock).
IntraLase will be obligated to use reasonable efforts to develop products
based upon the technology, and to give primary consideration to the maintenance of business offices in the state of Michigan.
No use of University services or facilities, nor any assignment of University
employees, will be obligated under the license and related agreements.
3.   The pecuniary interests of Drs. Kurtz and Juhasz arise from their equity
ownership interest in IntraLase, Inc. In accordance with the University
policy on intellectual property, they will waive any personal participation in
the sharing of revenues received by the University from IntraLase. (The
other inventors of the technology will share in such revenues in accordance
with University policy, on a pro rata basis under a sharing agreement
ratified by all inventors.)
Agreement between the University of Michigan and IntraLase
Corporation
On a motion by Regent McFee, seconded by Regent Power, the Regents
unanimously approved an agreement between the University of Michigan
and IntraLase Corporation ("IntraLase") under which IntraLase will fund

employees and directors and shareholders of IntraLase, this agreement falls
under the state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is provided in compliance with statutory requirements:


163




November Meeting, 1997


1.  Parties to the agreement are the University of Michigan and IntraLase
Corporation.
2.  The terms of the proposed agreement are acceptable and conform to University policy. Both Dr. Kurtz and Dr. Juhasz will perform work on behalf of
the University under this agreement. Neither of them will receive any
compensation from IntraLase and will not play any role on behalf of IntraLase
relative to this project. The amount of the subcontract to the University if
$10,000. Equipment valued at approximately two hundred thousand dollars

Corporation to add the University of Michigan's executive vice president for

chair and chief operating officer; to appoint the officers of MHC as follows:

officer, but that instead of designating in the bylaws which of the other directors
is going to hold the vice chair, treasurer, and secretary positions, the offices
be created and the board of directors be empowered to decide who among
them will hold which of these offices. This will provide more flexibility to the
board and the chair. She amended her motion to so state. The vote was
then taken, and the amended motion was approved unanimously.

Dear Regent McGowan:
President Bollinger asked that I respond to your letter of November 12, 1997, concerning the proposed expansion of Michigan Stadium.
The expansion of the Stadium will involve adding rows of seats at the perimeter of the
Stadium. Thus, the work itself will not impact the area devoted to Commencement seating.
However, we e   be working closely with the Office of Major Events in the University s
Development Office to be certain that the project does not intrude on the ceremony.
Although contracts have not yet been issued, they will include provisions that all work
will be stopped and the construction site cleaned prior to Commencement. Furthermore,
equipment and material marshaling areas will be located so as to not affect access to the
Stadium by Commencement participants and guests. These provisions will be reviewed by
Executive Vice President Kasdin.
With respect to your question concerning funding provisions, a number of facts make
us quite conifortable that ticket sales will indeed cover the cost of the expansion:
*    For some time, we have been experiencing a 98% season ticket renewal rate.
*    Based on unfilled requests, we estimate that there is a current unmet need for
1,500 to 2,000 additional non-student season tickets.
*    This year the demand for students tickets exceeded supply by 3,000 season
tickets, making necessary the use of a lottery to allocate partlal season tickets.
*    The recent addition of Penn State to the league has generated a rivalry which we
believe will equal that between the University and Michigan State, Ohio State,
and Notre Dame. These rivalries serve to maintain interest in season tickets over
very long periods of time.
Nevertheless, should all of these factors prove inadequate the Athletic Director has
provided us with a letter pledging the use of Athretic Department Reserves as necessary.
Should you have any questions or require additional information, please let me know.
Sincerely,
C. W. Matthews

DECEMBER MEETING, 1997


The University of Michigan
Ann Arbor
Thursday, December 18, 1997
The Regents convened at 1:55 p.m. in the Regents' Room. Present were
President Bollinger and Regents Deitch, Maynard, McFee, McGowan, Newman,
Power, and Taylor. Also present were Executive Vice President Kasdin, Provost

General Remarks: President Bollinger
President Bollinger pointed out some of the accomplishments of faculty
and students since the last Regents' Meeting. He noted that Garry Brewer,
former dean of the School of Natural Resources and Environment, has been
named to a chair at a Swedish university that was established in honor of the
king. Also, among other honors received by the University of Michigan
football program, player Charles Woodson had received the Heisman Trophy
and Coach Lloyd Carr had been named coach of the year. Finally, he pointed
out that Fiona Rose, former president of Michigan Student Assembly, had
received a Rhodes Scholarship, the 24th University of Michigan student and
the first since 1993 to have been so honored.
Regents' Resolution in Honor of Fiona Anne Rose
President Bollinger called on Regent Rebecca McGowan, who called Ms.
Rose to the podium. Regent McGowan observed that Michigan had nominated
four outstanding students for Marshall and Rhodes Scholarships and noted
that the relationship between all four of them had been extremely strong and
supportive throughout the process. She then read the following resolution:
Regents' Resolution
The Regents of the University of Michigan congratulate and
commend Fiona Anne Rose on her selection as a 1998 Rhodes
Scholar. She exemplifies the high standards which the scholarship
celebrates: intellectual and scholastic attainments, integrity, interest
in and respect for other human beings, leadership, energy to use
talents to the fullest, and a fondness for and success in sports. It is a
great honor for her and for the University of Michigan.
One of thirty-two students selected nationwide to receive the
prestigious Rhodes Scholarship, Ms. Rose has distinguished herself as a
strong and effective leader at the University of Michigan and
nationally. As the 1996-97president of the Michigan Student Assembly,


169




December Meeting, 1997


Ms. Rose ably represented the interests and concerns of students to the
Regents and to the administration and did so with utmost tact,
integrity, and graciousness. She has served on many University committees
and task forces, including the Task Force on Child Care. In February
1996, Ms. Rose spoke eloquently on behalf of students at Michigan and
across the country to President Bill Clinton and Congressional leaders
about the importance of student financial aid.
In addition to student government, Ms. Rose works many hours
each week assisting a deaf student and is a former member of the women's
crew team and of the University Philharmonic Orchestra. This past
summer she participated in an archeological dig in Pompeii. An honors
student, Ms. Rose plans to continue to study classical archeology at
Oxford University and to pursue a career in public service, possibly in
education or public policy.
It is with pride that the Regents congratulate Fiona Anne Rose on
her selection as a 1998 Rhodes Scholar and wish her great success as
she continues her formal education at Oxford.
There followed a round of applause. Ms. Rose thanked the Regents for

administration during and after her tenure in student government.
Report: Research and Scholarly Activities, 1997-Measure by Measure
Vice President Neidhardt distributed a report titled "Research and
Scholarship: Expenditures, Proposals, and Awards, FY1997," noting that the
report provides an assessment of the University's research efforts during the
past fiscal year. He also distributed an outline of his presentation, titled
"Research and Scholarly Activities FY 1997: Measure by Measure."
Vice President Neidhardt noted that the University is currently the
nation's number one research university, measured by the volume of its
annual expenditures in support of research and scholarly activity, which
amounted to $458,478,301 in 1996-97. He noted that whereas two years ago a
drop of 33 percent in federal nondefense R&D expenditures had been predicted
by the year 2002, in 1997 this amount had been reduced to 23 percent. More
recently, the decline in expenditures has been projected to amount to 14
percent by 2002.
Vice President Neidhardt reviewed the reasons for this, noting that
leaders of both political parties in Congress have recently voiced strong
support for research funding by federal agencies. He noted that budgets for
the National Institutes of Health and the National Science Foundation have
risen substantially for FY 1998. These changes can be attributed to intensive
educational efforts on the part of the research community and to the strong
state of the nation's economy.
Vice President Neidhart displayed charts illustrating the percentage of
the University's research expenditures by sponsor group and by university
unit for FY 1997, comparisons of the research portfolio by fields of study
since 1987, and the ten-year trend in research expenditures by federal and


170




December Meeting, 1997


nonfederal sources. He noted that while several of the University of
Michigan's peer institutions have seen significant declines in recent years in
the percentage of total federal research funding they receive, the percentage
received by the University of Michigan has risen to just over two percent of the
national research expenditure over the past decade.
He concluded that University of Michigan faculty have been successfully
competing for their share of the federal investment in research, and that every
effort should be made to nurture new avenues of inquiry by the faculty. This
includes providing seed funds for new explorations, establishment of incubator
units, and cost sharing and infrastructure support of research. The University
should continue its efforts to inform Congress and the public of the continued
need for university-based research. It should also adopt a budget model that will
protect the tradition of cross-disciplinary and cross-unit collaboration in
research. Finally, it should retain the core value that research and educational
objectives are interwoven and essential for the preservation of the University's
uniqueness.
In response to a question from President Bollinger about research
facilities, Vice President Neidhardt noted that the University has excellent
new buildings in the College of Engineering and in the Medical Center, but it
is always difficult to find funding for obtaining the latest technology to keep
faculty at the cutting edge of research. Provost Cantor pointed out the
important role of seed funding provided by the Office of the Vice President
for Research for "incubator units" on campus. But she noted that funding
for the arts and humanities has lagged behind that for the hard sciences.
In response to a question from Regent Power, it was noted that
discussions are underway within the University about the indirect cost
recovery rate.
Enrollment Planning
Provost Cantor observed that enrollment planning involves balancing
accessibility with maintaining a high quality of life and education for
students. That is, the University wants to provide extraordinary quality for
as many students as possible. There are a number of policies and procedures
in place both for housing and enrollment management, but given the large
pool of qualified applicants, this is a very difficult task and is a delicate
balancing act involving the schools and colleges, offices of the provost and
vice president for student affairs, and many other areas of the University.
Housing Occupancy Report
Vice President Hartford distributed documents explaining the housing
situation and options for 1998-99. She noted that a lot of misinformation
had been spread in recent weeks and gave a report describing the actual
situation.
Vice President Hartford noted that first-year students have historically
been guaranteed space in traditional residence halls. However, for the past
four years, University Housing has had a supply/demand problem, due to an
increase of 500 freshman students during this time and a concurrent increase


171




December Meeting, 1997


in the number of upper division students interested in living on campus.
This has led to overcrowding in the traditional residence halls, in which
there are 7600 spaces.
She reported that about 25 percent of all students live in "traditional"
and "nontraditional" residence halls, 4.5 percent live in family housing, 6.5
percent live in fraternities and sororities, 1.6 percent live in cooperatives,
almost 44 percent live in private-sector rentals, and about 18 percent
commute. She clarified that there is space on campus for any students
currently in the University housing system who want to remain in the
system, which includes traditional and nontraditional residence halls.
Vice President Hartford stated that the guiding principles of University
Housing are to guarantee traditional hall space for first year students; to
serve the priorities of the living-learning programs, which include a
sophomore year component; and to assist junior and senior students, who are
more ready for and interested in independent living, either in living in
nontraditional halls or in finding off campus housing.
Current issues are the increased size of the first-year class, a higher
residence hall re-application rate among returning residents, and the need to
reduce overcrowding in the residence halls. However, she reiterated that
space is guaranteed in the system for any student who wants to live there,
and that meal programs are available for any student, whether or not they
live in residence halls.
Vice President Hartford reported that 96 percent of first-year students
live in traditional halls, as well as 36 percent of sophomores, 5 percent of
juniors and seniors, and less than one percent of graduate students. Regent
Taylor suggested that a survey be conducted to determine how many juniors
and seniors would choose to live in traditional halls if that option were
available. That information could be used to establish a vision of what the
ideal situation would be given sufficient resources.
Vice President Hartford noted that including overflow triple spaces and
additional spaces in Baits Hall, the total available traditional housing spaces
equal 7,980 for 1998-99. However, the estimated demand will equal 8,350,
leaving 370 students who would have to be housed in nontraditional halls.
Nontraditional halls have fewer staff and no formal programming, and their
leases do not include a meal plan, although plans can be purchased. She
pointed out that this past year, eight Big Ten schools opened with some
students in temporary housing; the 34 students at the University of
Michigan who had to be housed in lounges at the start of school had been
moved out of the lounges within 11 days.
Regent Taylor noted that he assumes that staff is working as hard as
possible to deal with the current situation; however, the other issue, which is
not being addressed, is the longer-range issue of the vision for housing and
what is and should be offered. Regent Power pointed out that historically,
there have been Regents who did not want to conduct a survey of housing
needs because they felt they represented the Ann Arbor landlord community,
and this precluded there being any long-term policy setting about housing.


172




December Meeting, 1997


He believes the Board is now in a position to set a forward-looking, long-term
policy to deal with the interests of the University in the area of housing.
Regent Deitch pointed out that the Board had been receiving a lot of
complaints about the housing situation, but that these should be viewed in
the context of allocating resources and cost/benefit analysis for all 23,500
undergraduate students. He believes the primary emphasis should be on
exposing the largest possible number of students to the benefits of a
Michigan education. At the current time, he noted, there appears to be a
shortage of rooms, and he believes that a rational solution has been arrived
at. He expressed concern about conducting a broad survey, as it could raise
unrealistic expectations about potential solutions.
Regent Taylor agreed that the current situation is being resolved in a
reasonable manner. However, it only emphasizes the need to look forward to
the future and collect data. Regent Newman agreed that a cohesive housing
policy is needed. Vice President Hartford agreed that there has not been a
broad discussion of what the University should be doing in this area in the
best of all possible worlds.
Regent McFee observed that most of the concerns raised by the current
situation have been answered by today's presentation. She expressed regret
that rumors had escalated to the point that so many unnecessary worries had
been caused.
Regent Maynard suggested that administrators look back and see what
in the system had created the misunderstandings in order to prevent this
unfortunate situation from recurring. Vice President Hartford observed that
sometimes when proposals are raised in order to receive open discussion and
input, people assume that the decision has already been made.
Regent Deitch disagreed that the University does not have a cohesive
housing policy. He believes the housing division is well-run, that decisions
are made based upon historic usage, and that the plant has been suitably
updated. Any review of the assumptions underlying the way the Housing
Division operates should be conducted in the context of all other demands on
the University's resources.
Regents Newman and Taylor reiterated that they are not suggesting
that the Housing Division is not well-run; they are only suggesting that the
issue needs to be reviewed in order that a cohesive plan be developed. Vice
President Hartford emphasized that what should drive the housing policy is
the academic mission of the institution.
Operating Principles of Enrollment Management
Provost Cantor then gave a presentation about enrollment management.
She noted that enrollments have been relatively steady over the past ten
years. She said there is a good deal of coordination among all of the offices
concerned with enrollment, including the schools and colleges, admissions
office, provost's office, office of financial aid, and office of budget and
planning. She noted that enrollment targeting has as much to do with
classroom space as it does with housing. She displayed a chart showing the


173




December Meeting, 1997


enrollment planning timeline and noted that the need for determining
housing needs for upper division students comes much earlier than when the
size of the freshman class is known and before the number of returning
students is known.
For Fall 1997, there was a much higher yield rate than expected for
resident students (residents of the state of Michigan who decide to attend the
University). She pointed out that many of the factors that affect yield rate
are not easy to incorporate into enrollment projection models.
Regent Newman suggested that information sent to prospective
students include a statement that housing is not guaranteed after the
freshman year, as a number of parents had indicated that they were unaware
of this policy.
Provost Cantor noted that although the number of incoming students
was higher than had been projected, the increased numbers of students this
year represent only one-half of one percent of the total enrollment. This is
within the desired enrollment target projection range.  However, she
reiterated that academic initiatives, such as classroom and living/learning
experiences, are also important in determining enrollment targets. To this
end, she noted that the College of Literature, Science, and the Arts is
considering reducing the target for the next freshman class by 100 students
in order to increase the availability of small first-year seminar classes. This
number would be offset by increasing the number of upper-division transfer
students.
Regent Newman pointed out that it would be better to have admissions
policy decisions impact the housing situation than for housing availability to
impact enrollment.  That is, academic decisions, rather than housing
availability, should be the driving factors for decisions on enrollment
decreases. General agreement was expressed on this point.
Executive Session Motion
Regent Power made the following motion:
Pursuant to Sections 8(e) and 8(h) of the Open Meetings Act, as
amended by 1984 PA 202 and 1996 PA 464, I move that the Board of
Regents meet in closed session on December 18, 1997, in the Regents'
Room, for the purposes of consulting with our attorney regarding trial
or settlement strategy in connection with specific pending litigation
(Section 8e) and of considering material exempt from discussion or
disclosure by the Michigan Freedom of Information Act (Section 8h).
Such exempt material consists of a written opinion from the Board's
legal counsel.
Regent Deitch seconded the motion, and it was approved unanimously.
Regent Power added, "In addition, during this session we will consider a
periodic personnel evaluation of an employee who has requested a closed
hearing (Section 8a)."

Retirement Memoirs. Provost Cantor submitted thirteen retirement
memoirs.
John Russell Brown, professor of theatre and drama in the School of
Music and professor of English language and literature in the College of
Literature, Science, and the Arts, will retire from active faculty status on
December 31, 1997.
Professor Brown received his B.A. (1949) and M.A. (1952) degrees from
Oxford University and his Ph.D. degree in 1960 from the University of
Birmingham. From 1951-57, he was a fellow, then dean at the Shakespeare
Institute, Stratford-upon-Avon. He then served as lecturer and senior lecturer
(1957-63) in the Department of English, then head of the Department of Drama
and Theatre Arts (1963-71) at the University of Birmingham (England). He
was a professor of English at the University of Sussex from 1971-82 and
professor of theatre arts at the State University of New York at Stony Brook
from 1982-85. He came to the University of Michigan in 1985 as professor
and chair of the Department of Theatre and Drama and professor of English
language and literature.
Professor Brown is a scholar who loves the stage. His scholarly work has
always been informed by a special awareness of the practical realities of
theater, and this orientation has defined his prominence among Shakespeare
scholars for 40 years. His earliest successes stemmed from a fresh insistence
that Shakespeare's plays be treated as stage pieces rather than as texts simply
to be read. Shakespeare's Plays in Performance (1966) and Free Shakespeare
(1974) have remained influential in this crusade to this day. Somewhat later,
he served for 15 years as associate director of the National Theatre in
London, searching for important modem works for the stage while at the
same time breathing fresh new life into old ones. Later still, he began to
direct performances of Elizabethan and modern works. He has directed
professional productions at theaters in England and in the United States, as
well as numerous student productions at the University of Michigan and
elsewhere. He recently edited and contributed to The Oxford Illustrated
History of Theatre (1995) and currently has several books in press.
A vibrant, challenging teacher, Professor Brown addressed large issues,
asked big questions, and wanted expansive responses from students. His
excitement and authority could sometimes intimidate at first, but students
invariably became Brown enthusiasts.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming
John Russell Brown professor emeritus of theatre and drama and professor
emeritus of English language and literature.
Thomas N. Filson, associate professor of education at the University of
Michigan-Flint, retired from active faculty status on May 31, 1997.


185




December Meeting, 1997


Professor Filson received his A.B. degree at Chico State College (California)
in 1954 and his Ph.D. degree at the University of Minnesota in 1957. From
1957-60, he taught at Hastings College (Nebraska) and then Hastings Public
Schools. He was an assistant, then associate, professor at Western Illinois
University from 1960-67. He joined the University of Michigan-Flint faculty in
1967 as an associate professor of education.
During his thirty years on the faculty, Professor Filson has taught courses
in educational foundations, educational psychology, and principles of psychology
and has supervised student teachers and students in fieldwork placements. A
specialist in instructional psychology and human learning, he is the author of
Instructional Decision Making (William Brown Book Company, 1969).
Professor Filson has played a leadership role in establishing the undergraduate
foundations block program. The foundations block is an innovative approach
to initiating students into teacher education through a coordinated experience
involving a fieldwork placement in schools, a reflective seminar, and coursework
in social foundations of education and educational psychology. Working with
other members of the department, Professor Filson helped establish the
foundations block and served for many years as the coordinator of the block
experience.
During the 1993-94 academic year, Professor Filson was interim chair of
the education department. Throughout his career, he has played an active
role in faculty governance. He has served on a number of key departmental
committees, and most recently, as chair of the College of Arts and Sciences
Curriculum Committee. A dedicated teacher and mentor, Professor Filson
has devoted his career to helping undergraduates become distinguished
teachers.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his
dedicated service by naming Thomas N. Filson associate professor emeritus
of education.
Ilene H. Forsyth, Arthur F. Thurnau Professor of History of Art and
professor of history of art in the College of Literature, Science and the Arts,
will retire from active faculty status on December 31, 1997.
Professor Forsyth received her A.B. degree from the University of
Michigan in 1950 and her A.M. and Ph.D. degrees in 1955 and 1960,
respectively, from  Columbia University.  She joined the University of
Michigan faculty as a lecturer in 1961. She was promoted to assistant
professor in 1963, associate professor in 1968, and professor in 1974. She was
named Arthur F. Thurnau Professor in 1984.
Professor Forsyth's first book, The Throne of Wisdom: Wood Sculptures
of the Madonna in Romanesque France (Princeton University Press, 1972)
received the prestigious Charles Rufus Morey Book Award of the College Art
Association of America in 1974. It is a classic in the field, posing a series of
questions about tradition, style, liturgical function, and social context that are
still the foci of fruitful debate. In addition to a long list of important edited
volumes, articles, and reviews, she has also published The Uses of Art:
Medieval Metaphor in the Michigan Law Quadrangle (University of Michigan
Press, 1993), for which she received the Annie Award for Excellence in the Arts
from the Washtenaw Council for the Arts. A monograph, The Romanesque


186




December Meeting, 1997


Sculpture of Saint-Andoche, Saulieu, is among major scholarly works
forthcoming.
Students in a wide range of specializations have benefited from the
rigorous training provided by Professor Forsyth. Her status as a board
member of many national and international organizations has helped shape
the field of art history and has lent special prestige to the University of
Michigan. Her energy and commitment have made her a mainstay of the
department and of the broader University; she has served on numerous
departmental, college, and University-wide committees.
Professor Forsyth has been honored by appointments as visiting
professor at Harvard University (1980), Andrew Mellon Professor at the
University of Pittsburgh (1981), and distinguished professor of medieval
studies at the University of California at Berkeley (1996). She has been
appointed Kress Professor at the National Gallery of Art for 1998-99.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming Ilene
H. Forsyth Arthur F. Thurnau Professor Emerita of History of Art and professor
emerita of history of art.
Richard W. Fortner, professor of management and former dean of the
School of Management at the University of Michigan-Flint, will retire from
active faculty status on December 31, 1997.
A native of Indiana, Professor Fortner received his B.S. (1953), M.B.A.
(1954), and D.B.A. (1964) degrees from Indiana University. From 1954-80, he
taught at the U.S.A.F. Institute of Technology, Wittenberg University,
Indiana University, and the University of Rochester. He joined the University of
Michigan-Flint in 1980 as dean of the School of Management. During his
tenure as dean, he was instrumental in attaining accreditation from the
American Assembly of Collegiate Schools of Business for the undergraduate
program in 1982 and graduate business programs in 1986, and re-accreditation
in 1992.
Professor Fortner's honors include the United States Steel Foundation
Fellowship, the Indiana CPA's Gold Watch Award, and Indiana University
Business School's Senior Rawles Prize. He was awarded the Legion of Merit
by the U.S. Air Force for his performance as senior reservist in the U.S.A.F.
Systems Command Directorate of Contracting and Manufacturing. He is a
member of Phi Eta Sigma, Beta Gamma Sigma, and Beta Alpha Psi.
Professor Fortner has been a member of the Michigan Society of CPAs; the
Rochester, New York, Chamber of Commerce (member, Finance Committee,
1963-80); American Accounting Association; the Institute of Management
Accountants (director of the Rochester Chapter from 1966-73); the Consortium
for Graduate Study in Management (member of the board of directors and of
the executive committee, 1968-80); the New York Society of CPA's (member,
board of directors of the state society and of the executive board, Rochester
Chapter, 1975-78); Graduate Management Admission Council (Rochester
representative, 1974-80; member of the board of trustees, 1976-80; chair,
1978-79); and the Reserve Officers Association. On the Flint campus, Professor
Fortner has served on numerous departmental and campus-wide committees.
His community activities include membership in the Rotary Club of Flint, the
Greater Flint Arts Council, the New Vic Dinner Theatre, and the Friends of
WFBE-FM Radio.

December Meeting, 1997


The Regents now salute this distinguished business educator for his
dedicated service by naming Richard W. Fortner professor emeritus of
management and dean emeritus.
Albert I. Hermalin, professor of sociology and research scientist at the
Population Studies Center, College of Literature, Science, and the Arts, will
retire from active faculty status on December 31, 1997.
Professor Hermalin received his B.S. degree in 1949 from City College of
New York and his M.A. (1966) and Ph.D. (1969) degrees from Princeton
University. He joined the University of Michigan faculty in 1967 as a lecturer
in sociology and research associate in the Population Studies Center. He was
promoted to assistant professor in 1969, associate professor in 1972, and
professor in 1978. Within the Population Studies Center, Professor Hermalin
served as associate director from 1972-76, director from 1977-87, and interim
director in 1990-91. He was promoted to research scientist in 1987.
Early in his career, Professor Hermalin and his collaborators carried out
pioneering investigations of the transition from very high to very low birth
rates in Taiwan. Due to these efforts, this demographic change, which has
occurred in many nations, is more completely understood and better
documented in Taiwan than in any other nation. After birth rates fall
rapidly, the age structure of the population shifts and the challenges of an
aging population begin to appear. By the 1980s, Professor Hermalin had
become a leader in the demography of aging, especially within East and
Southeast Asia. Due to his efforts, major funding was obtained from the
National Institute on Aging to create the Michigan Exploratory Center on the
Demography of Aging-a now thriving program that is promoting excellent
demographic research.
Professor Hermalin has also been an effective mentor for dozens of
doctoral students. During his tenure as director of the Population Studies
Center, he was responsible for obtaining major funding from the National
Institutes of Child Health and Human Development. Due to his fundraising
efforts and his exceptionally skillful management, the Population Studies Center
should continue for many years to be one of the nation's outstanding centers for
population research and doctoral training.
In 1989, Professor Hermalin was awarded the Robert J. Lapham Prize by
the Population Association of America for his contributions to the discipline.
He served as president of that organization in 1993.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Albert I.
Hermalin professor emeritus of sociology and research scientist emeritus.
Peter B. Kaufman, professor of biology, College of Literature, Science
and the Arts, will retire from active faculty status on December 31, 1997,
following 41 years of service.
Professor Kaufman received his B.Sc. degree in 1949 from Cornell
University and his Ph.D. degree in 1954 from the University of California at
Davis. After a year of postdoctoral study at The Ohio State University, Dr.
Kaufman joined the University of Michigan faculty in 1956 as an instructor.
He was promoted to assistant professor in 1957, associate professor in 1962,
and professor in 1972.


188




December Meeting, 1997


Professor Kaufman's early interest in the action of herbicides on weeds
expanded into a research program that explored various aspects of plant growth
and development, including the roles of hormones and of environmental factors,
such as gravity, on plants.  These activities resulted in a number of
publications. In his studies of plant development, Professor Kaufman has
conducted research on the actions of hormones such as the gibberillins on
stem growth. Additional work has addressed the influence of gravity on this
process, a phenomenon known as gravitropism. A third area of investigation
by Professor Kaufman's group has been the elucidation of structural details of
the plant cell wall, a cellular structure that is intimately involved in stem
growth and development.
Professor Kaufman's classroom activities included teaching popular
courses on the topic of organismal plant biology. Several generations of
students have profited from their exposure to "Plants and Man" and to the
course he taught on plant biotechnology for a number of years. His teaching
activities led to the production of textbooks used in introductory plant
courses, and he was featured in "The House Botanist," a series of educational
television programs produced by the University of Michigan Television
Center.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming
Peter B. Kaufman professor emeritus of biology.
John H. Lillie, D.D.S., professor of anatomy and cell biology in the
Medical School and professor of dentistry in the School of Dentistry, will
retire from active faculty status on January 5, 1998.
After attending Kalamazoo College from 1959-62, Dr. Lillie received
D.D.S., M.S., and Ph.D. degrees from the University of Michigan in 1966,
1969, and 1972, respectively. He joined the University of Michigan faculty in
1972 as an assistant professor in the Medical School and in the School of
Dentistry. He was promoted to associate professor of dentistry in 1978,
associate professor of anatomy in 1979, professor of anatomy in 1985, and
professor of dentistry in 1991. From 1989-91 he also served as interim
assistant dean for pre doctoral education in the School of Dentistry.
Dr. Lillie has had a distinguished career as a gross anatomist, having
applied his clinical knowledge of dentistry to undergraduate and graduate
dental teaching in a number of anatomy courses. He is an acknowledged
expert in this field, and his recent book, Sectional Anatomy of the Head and
Neck, is a real testimony to his skills and impact in that area. Also extremely
effective in the classroom, Dr. Lillie has received eight awards for his dental
teaching.
For many years, Dr. Lillie directed an important research program on
basement membrane biology. Most recently, he coordinated the electron
microscopy component of a groundbreaking study involving the digital
electron microscopic imaging and montaging of human nerve biopsies.
During his tenure as interim assistant dean, Dr. Lillie played a very
influential role in the administration of the School of Dentistry. He has also
served the University well in the sphere of administration at other levels.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member for his
dedicated service by naming John H. Lillie, professor emeritus of anatomy
and cell biology and professor emeritus of dentistry.

December Meeting, 1997


S. Martin Lindenauer, M.D., professor of surgery, retired from active
faculty status on June 30, 1997, after a most productive career as a teacher,
researcher, and clinician.
A native of New York, Dr. Lindenauer attended Dartmouth College from
1950-53. He then entered Tufts Medical School, where he received his M.D.
degree in 1957. He served his internship at the U.S. Army Hospital, Fort
Benning, Georgia, followed by a residency in general surgery at the University
of Michigan from 1960-64. He joined the University of Michigan faculty in
1964 as an instructor in surgery and was promoted to assistant professor in
1967, associate professor in 1969, and professor in 1972.
From 1968-75, Dr. Lindenauer was chief of the surgical service at the
Ann Arbor Veterans Administration Hospital, and from 1974-81 he served
that institution as chief of staff. He was also an associate dean of the Medical
School from 1974-81 and was associate chief of clinical affairs at University
Hospitals from 1984-88. Dr. Lindenauer's research, evident in over 175
scientific publications, included seminal contributions on the development of
both biologic and synthetic vascular grafts. His laboratory studies of the
microcirculation were among the first to define the importance and control of
arteriovenous anastomoses.  His clinical research was far-ranging, with
important contributions on the management of pelvic neoplasms and the
diagnosis and treatment of both arterial and venous diseases.
Dr. Lindenauer mentored hundreds of students and was personally
responsible for developing the careers of dozens of young physicians who now
hold professorial positions at many of our nation's most prestigious medical
schools. His administrative leadership contributed greatly to the successful
academic mission of the Veterans Administration and University of Michigan
medical centers.
The Regents now salute this distinguished health educator for his
dedicated service by naming S. Martin Lindenauer professor emeritus of
surgery.
Paul J. Loos, D.D.S., associate professor of dentistry in the School of
Dentistry, will retire from active faculty status on December 31, 1997.
Dr. Loos received his B.S. and D.D.S. degrees from Creighton University
in 1954 and 1959, respectively, and his M.S. degree in pedodontics from the
University of Michigan in 1968. He joined the University of Michigan faculty
as an assistant professor in 1970 and was promoted to associate professor in
1974. Since 1971, Dr. Loos has held an appointment as an attending staff
member at University Hospitals. During this time, he served as chair of
Hospital Dentistry from 1979-87, director of Hospital Dentistry from 1987-91,
and director of the General Practice Residency program from 1983-86. He
also served as interim director of the pediatric dentistry graduate program in
the School of Dentistry from 1991-93.
Within the Department of Pediatric Dentistry, Dr. Loos has been a
strong participant in teaching and clinic activity and has served as chair of the
graduate student selection committee. He has also served on numerous
committees within the School of Dentistry, and during his appointment at
University Hospitals he was actively involved in the quality assurance
program, the planning committee for the Maternal and Child Health Care


190




December Meeting, 1997


Center, the ambulatory care committee, the patient care subcommittee, and
the Mott Hospital surgical advisory committee.
Over the years, Dr. Loos has served as a consultant for numerous

received the Presidential Award of Appreciation from the Michigan Academy

American Academy of Pediatric Dentistry, and is a member of Omicron

The Regents now salute this distinguished health sciences educator by
naming Paul J. Loos associate professor emeritus of dentistry.
Melvin Manis, professor of psychology, will retire from active faculty
status on December 31, 1997.
Professor Manis received his A.B. degree from Franklin and Marshall
College in 1951 and his Ph.D. degree from the University of Illinois in 1954.
From 1954-58, he served first as a Public Health Service commissioned officer
in Washington, D.C., and then as an instructor in the psychology department
of the University of Pittsburgh. He came to Ann Arbor in 1958 as chief of the
Psychology Research Section of the VA Medical Center, a position he held
until 1989, and as a lecturer in the University of Michigan Department of
Psychology. He was promoted to associate professor in 1961, received tenure
in 1963, and was promoted to professor in 1966. He has also held visiting
appointments at universities around the globe.
Professor Manis is one of the leading scholars in the area of attitudes and
social judgment. He has made outstanding contributions to our understanding
of human judgmental processes in 2 books, numerous chapters, and more than
60 peer-reviewed research articles. His work covers a wide range of judgmental
phenomena, including the operation of standards, the emergence of assimilation
and contrast effects, the role of stereotypes and prejudice in person perception,
and the cognitive processes involved in assessing psychopathology. Several of
his papers have become classic citations in cognitive social psychology. His
outstanding reputation in the field is also reflected in his appointment as editor
of the Attitudes and Social Cognition Section of the Journal of Personality and
Social Psychology (1979-84), the most prestigious journal in personality and
social psychology.
Professor Manis has served on numerous committees for national
professional and governmental organizations. Within the University, he has
served on the Senate Assembly, as associate chair and chair of graduate
training of the psychology department, and as area chair of the social
psychology program, the personality program, and the joint program in social
psychology of the departments of psychology and sociology.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming
Melvin Manis professor emeritus of psychology.


191




December Meeting, 1997


George W. Morley, M.D., Norman F. Miller Professor of Gynecology
and professor of obstetrics and gynecology, will retire from active faculty
status on December 31, 1997.
Dr. Morley earned his B.S. (1944), M.D. (1949), and M.S. (1955) degrees and
completed his internship and residency training (1949-54), at the University of
Michigan. He joined the University of Michigan faculty in 1956 as an instructor
in obstetrics and gynecology. He was promoted to assistant professor in 1958,
associate professor in 1961, and professor in 1970. He became chief of the
Gynecologic Oncology Service in 1964 and director of the Gynecologic Oncology
Fellowship, which he initiated, in 1971. In 1987, he was named the first Norman
F. Miller Professor of Gynecology.
Dr. Morley is one of America's most distinguished gynecologic surgeons.
Board certified in obstetrics and gynecology in 1958 and in gynecologic oncology
in 1974, his academic pursuits have spanned the full breadth of obstetrics and
gynecology. He is best known for his work as a surgeon for benign and
malignant gynecologic disease. Dr. Morley's bibliography lists over 110 articles
and 15 book chapters, including major contributions on radical hysterectomy
and radical vulvectomy. He is best known for his work establishing the role of
pelvic exenteration in the treatment of recurrent cancer of the cervix. This
series has the highest five-year survival rate reported in the literature and
remains a landmark of success in treating recurrent pelvic neoplasm.
Dr. Morley has been elected president of the American College of
Obstetricians and Gynecologists, the Society of Pelvic Surgeons, the Society of
Gynecologic Oncologists, the Society of Gynecologic Surgeons, and the Norman
F. Miller Gynecologic Society. He has also served as a member of the board of
governors of the American College of Surgeons. He has three times been listed
as among America's ten best obstetricians and gynecologists.
In the operating room, Dr. Morley was not only a firm master, but also a
patient teacher, assuring that all members of the surgical team learned both
the fundamental principles and the final nuances of operative gynecology. He
is also an excellent lecturer and discussant. In recognition of Dr. Morley's
contributions, in 1993 the Gynecologic Oncology Service at the University of
Michigan Medical Center was named the George W. Morley Service. After an
extraordinarily short campaign, the George W. Morley Collegiate
Professorship was established.
The Regents now salute this distinguished physician and teacher by
naming George W. Morley the Norman F. Miller Professor Emeritus of
Gynecology and professor emeritus of obstetrics and gynecology.
Elizabeth Mutschler, associate professor of social work, will retire
from active faculty status on December 31, 1997.
Professor Mutschler received her Diploma in Social Work from the
School of Social Work in Ludwigsburg, Germany, in 1968, and received her
M.S.W. and Ph.D. degrees in 1972 and 1975, respectively, from Washington
University. From 1975-78, she served on the faculty of the University of
Maryland at Baltimore. She joined the University of Michigan School of
Social Work as an assistant professor in 1979 and was promoted to associate
professor in 1984.
Professor Mutschler's scholarly contributions have centered on three
areas: analysis of treatment procedures and therapists' behaviors that facilitate


192




December Meeting, 1997


client change; evaluation of factors related to therapists' use of empirical
procedures in clinical practice; and technology-based decision support and
information processing to help therapists identify treatment objectives and
monitor outcomes. Her work is highly-regarded, particularly her important
contributions on clinical evaluation and her activities in computer-assisted
decision-making. She conducted a landmark study of factors associated with
therapists' use of empirical procedures in clinical agency settings, and has
made groundbreaking advances in adapting computer technology to enhance
clinical decision-making. She continues to be an international leader in
computer technology for social work.
Within the School of Social Work, Professor Mutschler is known for
setting high standards in the classroom and for promoting the use of
computers in social work courses and practice. Her considerable service
contributions include her work on the University Research Priorities
Committee and on the Senate Assembly. She has assisted with management
information systems development at area hospitals and has conducted
workshops on technology for faculty and students. Professor Mutschler is
truly a pioneer, having forged significant new paths of learning and having
worked tirelessly to assist social workers around the world in achieving the
best possible modes of practice.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming
Elizabeth Mutschler associate professor emerita of social work.
Catherine A. Nadon-Gabrion, professor of music (music education) in
the School of Music and lecturer in education in the School of Education, will
retire from active faculty status on December 31, 1997.
Professor Nadon-Gabrion earned her B.Mus. (1962) and M.Mus (1966)
degrees at the New England Conservatory of Music and her Ed.D. degree in
1979 at the University of Massachusetts. From 1962-68 she was a public
school music teacher in Massachusetts. She served as assistant professor of
music at Westfield State College from 1968-72 and as coordinator of general
and choral music in the Montgomery County (Maryland) Public Schools from
1972-77. She joined the faculty of the University of Michigan as associate
professor of music in 1977 and was promoted to professor in 1994.
Professor Nadon-Gabrion was a dedicated teacher of teaching-herself
manifesting all of that profession's generous impulses and controversial
history in research universities. She well understands the challenges of
teaching in the public schools and is committed to providing realism,
relevance, and idealism in courses designed for prospective teachers. She
practiced "hands on" education and was immensely concerned for the
progress of students under her tutelage. She maintained that elusive balance
between a nurturing, supportive rapport versus requisite honesty in
evaluation of students' work. She was an energetic motivator.
Professor Nadon-Gabrion built a formidable reputation on practical
applications of strategies for successful teaching in general music classrooms
in public schools. Her numerous textbooks reached a sizable percentage of
elementary students in the United States. Partially as a result of the
prominence brought about by this authorship, Professor Nadon-Gabrion is in
constant demand as a speaker at music education conferences, school
districts, and sister institutions of higher education. Since 1990, she has led


193




December Meeting, 1997


workshops, lectured, and consulted in 21 states and in Germany, Japan,
Panama, and South Korea. Her energy and enthusiasm capture a crowd, and
teachers have returned to their classrooms enriched and invigorated.
Professor Nadon-Gabrion has made far-reaching contributions within her
profession.
The Regents now salute this distinguished faculty member by naming
Catherine A. Nadon-Gabrion professor emerita of music (music education).

memorials for faculty members, two students had died tragically within the
past two weeks. She expressed the University's condolences to the families.

Proposed License Agreement between the University of Mlc mgan
and IDE~, InCo
On a motion by Regent Newman, seconded by Regent Maynard, the
Regents unanimously approved a license agreement between the University
of Michigan and IDE, Inc. Regent Deitch was away from the table when the
vote was taken.
Because the owners of IDE, Inc., Drs. Les Rogers and Neal Clinthorne,
are also University of Michigan employees, this agreement falls under the
state of Michigan Conflict of Interest Statute. The following information is
provided in compliance with statutory requirements:
1.  Parties to the agreement are the University of Michigan and IDE, Inc.


195




December Meeting, 1997


2.   Terms of the agreement include:
The contracts to be completed between the University and IDE include the
license to be executed as well as documents covering stock transfers and
related matters. A sponsored research contract between the University and
IDE, Inc., will be the subject of a separate Regental action request.
The license will provide IDE, Inc., with exclusive rights to the technology for
the field of x-ray and gamma-ray imaging applications. The University will
retain ownership of the technology, internal research use rights, the right to
convey the standard governmental license, and commercialization rights in
fields outside of the field granted exclusively to IDE, Inc.
The University will receive a royalty of 1.0% to 2.0% (depending upon the
patentability of the incorporated technology) of all net sales of products of
IDE, Inc., and 20% of all royalties IDE, Inc., receives from sublicensees. The
University will also receive a modest minimum annual royalty of $5,000
beginning in 2000.
The license will require that IDE, Inc., secure at least $2,000,000 in outside
funding for the company's development activities by December 31, 1999.
Once that funding has been obtained, the University will receive equity
under a separate agreement equal to a number of shares which, after such
receipt, will equal 13% of the total number of shares issued to or reserved
for all parties in any way, including all options, warrants, and convertible
securities exercisable therefore, and all shares reserved for future issuance.
IDE, Inc., will be obligated to use its best efforts to develop products based
upon the technology and to give primary consideration to the maintenance
of business offices in the state of Michigan.
No use of University services or facilities, nor any assignment of University
employees, will be obligated under the license and agreements related
thereto. As previously noted, a sponsored research contract between the
University and IDE, Inc., will be the subject of a separate Regental action
request.
3.   Drs. Rogers' and Clinthorne's pecuniary interests arise from their equity
ownership interest in IDE, Inc. In accordance with the University Policy on
Intellectual Property, they will waive any personal participation in the
sharing of revenues received by the University from IDE, Inc. (The other
inventors of the technology will share in such revenues in accordance with
the University policy, on a pro rata basis under a sharing agreement ratified
by all inventors.)

The following information is provided in compliance with statutory

196




December Meeting, 1997

Establishment of School of Education and Human Services at
UM-Flint
Chancellor Nelms observed that the proposed changes reflect the
maturation of the University of Michigan-Flint, from its founding in 1965 as
a liberal arts college to its current configuration that includes a number of
professional programs. He noted that currently, education is the single
largest major on the campus and that the Flint campus is the largest
provider of teachers for the Flint/Mid-Michigan region of the state. Creation
of the School of Education and Human Services will allow the campus to
respond more effectively to the needs of the urban environment in which the
campus is located.
He noted that faculty consultation will continue to be sought as the new
structure is implemented and announced that the Charles Stewart Mott
Foundation has made a commitment of $1.5 million to implement the new
structure.  This grant will provide administrative support and faculty
positions, enabling the campus to improve its service learning programs.
President Bollinger commented that the Ann Arbor campus fully
supports this proposal. Regent McFee inquired whether the "Communities
in Schools" program is active in the city of Flint. Chancellor Nelms
responded that one of the faculty positions to be funded by the program will
serve as a resource to the community. He noted that a number of
community leaders in Flint had visited schools in other states to see how the
community education movement operates. He said he anticipates that a
community education initiative will be announced in the coming months that
would be similar to, but somewhat different from, the original community
education movement. He noted that this movement had been started in
Flint and funded by the Mott Foundation about 25 years ago.
Regent Maynard observed that it is important that institutions in an
urban setting are relevant to the community, and that the new initiative was
very exciting in this regard.

December Meeting, 1997


Regent McGowan moved that the faculties of the Department of
Education and the Department of Social Work (both currently in the College
of Arts and Sciences) be united into one school, named the School of
Education and Human Services. Regent McFee seconded the motion, and it
was approved unanimously.
