Sally L. Allen, professor of biology, will retire from active faculty status on
May 31, 1998, following 31 years on the faculty at the University of Michigan.
Professor Allen received her A.B. degree from Vassar College in 1946 and
her Ph.D. degree from the University of Chicago in 1953. At Chicago, she
worked on the genetics of the mouse with two of the most famous geneticists
of the twentieth century, Sewall Wright and George Snell, who later received
a Nobel Prize for the work on which she participated. Professor Allen came to
the University of Michigan in 1953 as a research assistant in the Department
of Zoology, where she carried out research in the single celled ciliates. She
was promoted to associate professor of botany in 1967 and professor in 1971.
She also served as an associate dean of the College of LS&A from 1988-91.
For most of her career, Professor Allen's research has focused on the
genetics and evolution of the ciliated protozoa, an unusual group of organisms
with a bizarre life cycle that have produced many fundamental insights into the
functioning of all organisms. She is recognized as a national and international
leader in this field. For many years, she has served as editor of Genetics, the
field's premier scientific journal.
Professor Allen's classroom activities have centered around the large
junior-senior majors course in genetics. She strove long and hard to make
improvements in this course and to have it keep pace with the revolutionary
advances in this field. Her devotion to the honors course in genetics has
been much appreciated by past and present students alike.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Sally L.
Allen professor emerita of biology.
Richard D. Duke, professor of urban planning in the College of Architecture and Urban Planning, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1998.
Professor Duke received his B.S. degree (1952) from the University of
Maryland, his B.S. (1954) and Master of Urban Planning (1956) degrees from
Michigan State University, and his Ph.D. degree (1964) from the University
of Michigan. From 1958-67, he was an assistant professor (1958-63), associate


352




May Meeting, 1998


professor (1963-67), professor (1967), and director of the Urban-Regional
Research Institute (1966-67) at Michigan State University. He joined the
University of Michigan faculty as professor of urban planning in December 1967.
Professor Duke served as chair of the Urban Planning Program from
1976-82. He has taught a range of graduate-level courses to urban planning
students, with a particular concentration on gaming. He has served on a
number of dissertation committees and has also been an active member of
many program, college, and University committees.
Professor Duke has had an outstanding career as an educator. He is a
member of NASAGA (North American Gaming and Simulation Association)
and a founding member of both ISAGA (International Simulation and Gaming
Association) and IPEG (International Policy Exercise Group). A pioneer in the
field of gaming, he is internationally recognized for his contributions in the
field of simulation and gaming, not only for his theoretical work, but also for
the significant contributions he has made in making this approach to strategic
planning known throughout the world. He has authored numerous games,
books, and articles on gaming and simulation.
Professor Duke has received many awards, including the ISAGA 25th
Anniversary Award in 1995 for the founding of ISAGA and the ISAGA Medal
and the Medaille Praga Didacta in 1989. He received a National Science
Foundation Faculty Fellowship in 1962-63; studied in Germany as a Fulbright
Scholar in 1969; and was a fellow in the Netherlands Institute for Advanced
Study in 1973-74.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Richard D.
Duke professor emeritus of urban planning.
Joe G. Eisley, professor of aerospace engineering, will retire from
active faculty status on May 31, 1998, following a 42-year career at the
University of Michigan.
Professor Eisley received his B.S. degree in aeronautical engineering in
1951 from Parks College of St. Louis University and his M.S. and Ph.D.
degrees in 1952 and 1956, respectively, from the California Institute of
Technology. He joined the University of Michigan as an assistant professor
in 1956 and was promoted to associate professor in 1960 and professor in
1965. Professor Eisley also served as associate dean for curriculum and
continuing education in the College of Engineering from 1967-81.
Professor Eisley has done research in the areas of structural dynamics,
flutter, and computer graphics and has published extensively in the area of
nonlinear vibrations. He has been very effective in the teaching of structural
mechanics and in converting academic ideas into industrial practice. In 1989,
he published the textbook, Mechanics of Elastic Structures. Professor
Eisley's students have consistently rated him as an outstanding teacher. He
pioneered the use of energy methods in structural mechanics and guided the
department's program in structures in that direction. This has made the
department a leader in the methods that have culminated in the broad use of
the finite element method, with many students from other departments
attending the aerospace engineering department's structures courses.
One of Professor Eisley's emphases has been to increase minority and
female enrollment in the College of Engineering. He has served as a contact


353




May Meeting, 1998


for visits by minority students and for summer visits by women sponsored by the
Society for Women Engineers. He has served on the University's President's
Commission on Minority Affairs. Professor Eisley has also devoted much
effort to serving as undergraduate program advisor for aerospace engineering,
and has served on the departmental curriculum committee. He has been the
director of the Space Grant College activities at Michigan, dealing with
outreach at all educational levels, encouraging elementary school children to
become interested in space activities and high school students to take the
courses necessary to pursue a career in space-related activities.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Joe G. Eisley
professor emeritus of aerospace engineering.
Daniel N. Fader, professor of English, will retire from active faculty
status on May 31, 1998.
Professor Fader received his B.A. (1952) and M.A. (1954) degrees from
Cornell University and his Ph.D. degree (1962) from Stanford University.
He joined the University of Michigan faculty as an instructor in 1961. He
was promoted to assistant professor in 1963, associate professor in 1968, and
professor in 1973.
Professor Fader was, above all, a great storyteller, and in his teaching
(especially of Shakespeare) he drew students into the great narratives of
English literature. As a scholar he was a storyteller too, and he brought to
his work a persuasive and even compelling brilliance. He was in great
demand as a lecturer and a commencement speaker.
Early in his career at Michigan, he began working with juvenile offenders
at the Maxey School in Whitmore Lake. From his work with young people
there, he wrote a modest pamphlet: "Teaching English at Boys Training School"
(1965). Working with Professor Elton B. McNeil, he enlarged this small effort
into Hooked on Books (1966), a revolutionary affirmation of the transforming
power of literacy that has gone through successive editions and still influences teachers, parents, and students to believe that reading changes
children's lives.
Professor Fader also believed that the literacy of Michigan students
could be transformed if only teachers would be attentive to students' voices.
In 1976, he was named founding chair of the English Composition Board, a
faculty body which oversees literacy efforts in the College of LS&A. With his
colleagues, he visited high schools throughout the state to explain what kind
of literacy was expected at the U-M and how important it was that students
come prepared to learn.
Though Hooked on Books was his most influential publication, his books
The Naked Children (1971) and Paul and I Discover America (1975) were
also widely read. The former is an account of pupils disabled by the schools
in our nation's capital, the latter a road book in which he examined patriotism
and its transformation from his generation to his son's. Professor Fader told
stories about caring for others, and made others care to tell stories too. He
remains particularly proud of having been the 1952 National Collegiate
Billiards Champion.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Daniel N. Fader
professor emeritus of English.


354




May Meeting, 1998


Irene Fast, professor of psychology, will retire from active faculty status
on May 31, 1998.
Professor Fast received her A.B. degree from Bethel College in Kansas in
1951 and her Ph.D. degree from the University of Michigan in 1958. From
1958-63, she was a lecturer in the Department of Psychology. She left in 1963
to serve as chief of psychological services at the San Fernando Valley Child
Guidance Clinic in California but returned to the University of Michigan in
1965 as a lecturer in psychology. She was promoted to associate professor in
1968, professor in 1973, and professor of psychology in the Department of
Psychiatry in 1974. She served as associate director of the counseling center
from 1982-87.
Within the department, Professor Fast played a central, prolonged, and
demanding role in formal courses and agency supervision in the diagnostic
training of clinical psychologists. Also greatly valued was her assistance in
the complicated transition years as the Counseling Center was transformed
into the current University Center for the Child and Family.
Professor Fast's scholarly contributions have had a significant impact,
beginning with her early work on bereavement and on step-parenting and her
papers demonstrating the vital role of personality variables in vocational
choice. Subsequent investigations produced new perspectives on depression
and borderline personalities, especially with respect to nature of borderline
psychotic children. But perhaps her most compelling studies were set forth in
her books, Event Theory: A Piaget-L-reud Integration; Gender Identity: A
Differentiation Perspective; and the forthcoming Selving: A Relational Theory of
Self-Organization. Event Theory is a powerful recasting of concepts of early
development, pressing far beyond earlier work. Gender Identity builds a richly
textured new formulation of gender differentiation from wide-ranging sources
of evidence. Selving seeks to bring psychology back to the study of the
neglected I-Self (self as subject) component of William James' distinction of
I-Self vs. Me-Self (self as object), in the process drawing a persuasive picture of
a dynamic, relational self. Recognition of this remarkable set of contributions
has led to numerous roles on editorial and advisory boards and to the awarding
of distinguished honors from the American Psychological Association.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Irene Fast
professor emerita of psychology.
Carl Gans, professor of zoology in the Department of Biology and
adjunct curator, Museum of Zoology, College of Literature, Science, and the
Arts, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1998, following 25
years of service.
A native of Germany, Professor Gans fled the Nazis with his family and
entered the United States in 1939. He received his B.M.E. degree from New
York University in 1944 and then served in the U.S. Army from 1944-46. He
received his M.S. degree from Columbia University in 1950 and his Ph.D.
degree from Harvard University in 1957. From 1958-71, he was a faculty
member at the University of Buffalo (now SUNY at Buffalo). He joined the
University of Michigan faculty in 1971 as professor and chair of the Department
of Zoology.


355




May Meeting, 1998


During his tenure as chair of the zoology department, Professor Gans
participated in the merger of the Department of Botany and Zoology into
what became the present Department of Biology. Following his term as
chair, he continued as professor and served on numerous university and
college committees, including the LSA Executive Committee. In 1996, he
assumed the latest of many visiting professorships, this one in the Department
of Zoology at the University of Texas, Austin.
Professor Gans' research specialty is functional morphology, the fusion
of anatomy and physiology that aims to interpret biological structure in
terms of its function. Within this specialty, he has concentrated on reptiles
and amphibians, contributing importantly to such fundamental topics as
breathing, eating, and locomotion. His classroom activities were centered on
the course, "The Biology of Vertebrates," which was famous among undergraduates for the demanding laboratory involving vertebrate dissection;
among graduate student instructors for the high standards imposed; and
among counselors for the distinction of being one of the few courses that
students praised even when they did not received a good grade.
Professor Gans is known worldwide, due to the many working visits that
he made to universities and museums all over the globe and to his collecting
trips, exemplified by his role as founding patron of the Irula Snake-catcher's
Cooperative Society in Madra, India.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Carl Gans
professor emeritus of zoology.
Rosalie J. Ging, M.D., assistant professor of psychiatry, retired from
active faculty status on February 28, 1998, after a productive career as an
administrator, teacher, and clinician.
Dr. Ging received her A.B. degree in 1942 and her M.D. degree in 1945,
both from the University of Michigan. She completed a psychiatric residency
at the University of Kansas Medical Center in 1952. She joined the University of Michigan as an instructor in 1957 and was promoted to assistant
professor in 1965.
Dr. Ging was appointed as a staff psychiatrist at the Veteran's Administration Medical Center in 1956. She served as chief of the psychiatry service at
the Ann Arbor Veteran's Administration Medical Center from 1960-84 and as
acting chief from 1984-86. She was responsible for administering and coordinating clinical supervision and education of psychiatric residents and medical
students. She has been a fellow of the American Psychiatric Association since
1967 and was selected as Federal Professional Woman of the Year in Michigan
in 1972.
Dr. Ging continues her clinical activity as an attending psychiatrist with
the Consultation-Liaison Service. She is a consultant in the MCD Cardiology
Clinic. Dr. Ging's research activity includes a study of Cushing's patients
and involvement in Telemedicine for the Department of Psychiatry.
Dr. Ging's devoted loyalty as administrator, teacher, clinician, and
mentor has been recognized over the years. Her insightfulness, expertise, and
contributions to the department have been consistently recognized by
faculty, trainees, and staff.

May Meeting, 1998


The Regents now salute this distinguished member of the faculty for her
dedicated service by naming Rosalie J. Ging assistant professor emerita of
psychiatry.
Assya K. Humesky, professor of Slavic languages and literatures, will
retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1998.
Born in the former Soviet Ukraine, during World War II Professor
Humesky lived under German occupation and was sent to Austria to do forced
labor until the end of the war. After spending two years in displaced persons
camps in western Europe, she came to the United States and resumed her
studies. She received her B.A. degree in 1948 from Albertus Magnus College
in New Haven, Connecticut, and her M.A. and Ph.D. degrees, in 1951 and
1955, respectively, from Radcliffe College. Professor Humesky came to the
University of Michigan in 1953 as an instructor in Slavic languages and
literatures. She was promoted to assistant professor in 1959, associate
professor in 1961, and professor in 1967.
Among Professor Humesky's published works are articles dealing with
poetry and poetics as well as language teaching. The book that resulted from
her dissertation, Majakovsky and his Neologisms (Rausen, N.Y., 1964), is
unique in that it lists all the instances of word coinage by the famous
Russian poet. This book is well-known and used by many Slavic scholars.
Professor Humesky is also co-author of a widely acclaimed two-volume
Russian grammar, Modern Russian (Harcourt, Brace & World, N.Y., 1964,
1965) and the author of Modern Ukrainian, now in its sixth printing
(Canadian Institute of Ukrainian Studies, Edmonton-Toronto, 1980). The
Russian grammar was the first to use the audio-lingual approach and the
first to illustrate Russian intonation. The Ukrainian textbook is the most
widely used introductory grammar of the language in the world, including
Ukraine itself, where it is used in Kiev at the International Ukrainian
Studies Summer School.
Professor Humesky has served as president of a number of scholarly
organizations, including the Permanent Ukrainian Conference at Harvard,
the Slavic section of the Michigan Academy of Arts and Sciences, the American
Association for Ukrainian Studies, and others. She has directed scores of
doctoral dissertations and many of her former students are teaching throughout the United States.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Assya K.
Humesky professor emerita of Slavic languages and literatures.
Joachim W. Janecke, professor of physics in the College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1998.
Professor Jainecke received his Dipl.Phys. (1952) and his Dr.rer.nat.
(1955) degrees from the University of Heidelberg. He first came to the
University of Michigan in 1960 as a research associate and lecturer. After
leaving for Florida State University in 1962, he returned to the University of
Michigan in 1965 as an associate professor. He was promoted to professor in
1969. Professor Janecke has also been a frequent visiting professor at
laboratories in Germany, the Netherlands, Israel, and particularly Japan,


357




May Meeting, 1998


where he received a fellowship from the Japanese Society for the Promotion
of Science and a COE professorship from Osaka University.
Professor Janecke has served the University of Michigan in many roles,
including terms on the Rackham graduate school executive board, the Senate
Assembly, and on other University-wide committees. He has served as chair
or member of 29 dissertation committees. Professor Janecke was elected a
fellow of the American Physical Society in 1972 and has served as associate
editor of Atomic Data and Nuclear Tables, a standard reference source.
In a distinguished research career, Professor Janecke has contributed to
physics theory with the development of nuclear mass models that are widely
used in nuclear astrophysics and nuclear physics to predict masses for unstable
and unknown nuclei.   He has also coauthored the field's authoritative
compendium of beta-decay functions.
In experimental research, he has conducted precision measurements of
Coulomb energies in nuclei and other nuclear reaction measurements related
to the isospin part of the nuclear force. He has also performed systematic
studies of a-particle transfer reactions and clustering in nuclei, such as 2C
and 160, to very long-lived a-decaying nuclei, such as 238U. He has been at
the forefront in high-resolution studies of charge-exchange reactions and
giant resonances, which are manifestations of the nuclear many-body system.
He has performed reaction studies with short-lived unstable nuclear beams,
particularly with high-energy tritons.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Joachim W.
Janecke professor emeritus of physics.
Lawrence W. Jones, professor of physics in the College of Literature,
Science, and the Arts, will retire from active faculty status on May 31, 1998.
Professor Jones received his B.S. (1948) and M.S. (1949) degrees from
Northwestern University and his Ph.D. (1952) degree from the University of
California at Berkeley. He joined the University of Michigan faculty as an
instructor in 1952 and was promoted to assistant professor in 1956, associate
professor in 1960, and professor in 1963. He served as chair of the department from 1982-87.
During his first decade at Michigan, he collaborated intensively in the
Midwest Universities Research Association (MURA), an accelerator design
and development group that pioneered the concept of colliding beams and
other innovations now universal in modern accelerators. With colleague Kent
Terwilliger, he built a small electron accelerator that demonstrated a
number of the new concepts he had developed with MURA. This model
became the vehicle for his first participation in international conferences in
the 1950s and early 1960s. Since then, he has collaborated at most of the
major accelerator laboratories, most recently at CERN in Europe.
Professor Jones' detector contributions include development of the
luminescent (scintillation) chamber, various optical spark chamber concepts,
and the ionization calorimeter for hadron energy measurement. His accelerator
experiments include hadron cross sections, elastic and inelastic scattering,
particle production, dimuon production, prompt neutrino production, and
charm production by protons. During the 1980s, he served as leader of the


358




May Meeting, 1998


team that developed a state of Michigan site proposal for the national Superconducting Super Collider.
At a time when accelerator facilities could provide energies no higher
than 30 GeV, Professor Jones exploited cosmic rays for free quark searches
and for the study of strong interactions at energies above 100 GeV. His
expertise in both cosmic-ray and accelerator physics has made him a much
sought-after intermediary between the two groups. Recently he has been
part of a project to use lasers as compact electron accelerators for particle
physics-so-called "table-top accelerators." He has also made contributions
in medical radioisotope imaging and helped pioneer the concept of hydrogen
as an alternative chemical fuel.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Lawrence W.
Jones professor emeritus of physics.
Virginia C. Kane, associate professor of history of art, will retire from
active faculty status on May 31, 1998.
Professor Kane received her B.A. degree from Mount Holyoke College in
1956 and her M.A. degree from the Institute of Fine Arts, New York University,
in 1961. She earned her Ph.D. degree from Harvard University in 1969, with
a dissertation entitled "Chinese Bronze Vessels and their Inscriptions." She
came to the University of Michigan in 1969 as an instructor and was
promoted to assistant professor in 1970 and associate professor in 1975.
Throughout her career at the University, Professor Kane has been a
devoted teacher of Asian art and Buddhist studies. Although her specialized
research has focused on Chinese bronzes, her range in the classroom has
been extraordinary-moving across temporal and cultural expanses in China,
Japan, and Southeast Asia, tracing the story and meanings of international
Buddhism through the artistic record. A deeply learned scholar and a
demanding instructor, Professor Kane's seminars are widely acknowledged
by multiple generations of graduate students in the Department of History of
Art as a superb training ground in research methodology and pedagogy as
well as in the substantive areas under discussion around the table.
Professor Kane contributed significantly to the creation at Michigan of
an Asian art program of international acclaim. Her efforts to build the
department's visual resources in Asian art and to maintain and enhance the
quality of its publication, Ars Orientalis, leave an inspired legacy of her
commitment to excellence.
The Regents now salute this faculty member by naming Virginia C.
Kane associate professor emerita of history of art.
C. Philip Kearney, professor of education, School of Education, will

Professor Kearney received his B.A. and M.A. degrees from the University

served as assistant superintendent of the Orange Local School District in
Cleveland. From 1968-77, Professor Kearney served as associate superintendent
in various capacities for the Michigan Department of Education. From 1977-80,
